I think if Stanley Kramer is guilty of anything related to this character it is in trying to sell tickets. You have to understand that during that time period many non-blacks would expect, or should I say require, the character to be perfect. Ironically, some blacks were critical of the character having to be so perfect. In my opinion, the only heavy handed scene was when Katherine Hepburn fired her bigoted assistant. All of that aside, I thought the movie was excellent. The acting, obviously, was outstanding across the board. I wondered if it was a coincidence that Katherine Houghton's character sounded so much like her real life aunt Katharine Hepburn. And, as previously noted on several occasions, Spencer Tracy's speech in which he seemingly addressed his love, in real life, for Katherine Hepburn was ironic knowing he died shortly after filming was completed. And 1967 was a career year for Sidney Poitier. In addition to this movie he also starred in In The Heat Of The Night and To Sir, With Love. I would highly recommend this movie if for no other reason than the outstanding acting by a great cast.

reviews.review_title: Socially Relevant in its Time, Interesting Today
reviews.content: A black man dating a white woman today wouldn't be seen as shocking but it still could raise some eyebrows among certain social groups. This movie is a good lack at the changing times around when the film was made and features the acting of 3 actors who have a combined 7 best actor/actress Oscars between them. If not for the star power the film would probably be forgotten by today. This is probably more of an important film than a particularly good or interesting film.

reviews.review_title: He's a human being who happens to be a man who happens to be black.
reviews.content: With three huge hits in 1967, Sidney Poitier claimed his reign as the biggest star in Hollywood, over Redford, over Newman, over McQueen. No actor took on such films with social consequence and won both scorn and admiration for it. Controversy loomed because white audiences loved him, and for some black moviegoers considered him an "Uncle Tom". But if only a handful of bigoted white people came out of seeing a Sidney Poitier movie seeing an actor and a man rather than a black actor or a black man, then he made just as much headway in the civil rights movement as the marches did.Coming out just as the supreme court legalized interracial marriage, thus tackles the subject head on. Perhaps its too polite, too upper middle class, too clean cut, but there it is, an attempt to tackle a topical subject, and it opened a conversation where the answers are completely all over the map today.The beautiful Katherine Houghton comes home with a surprise for her "nice" parents, Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn, decent people but stunned by the news. Actually, Hepburn is more open to the idea, as earthy and understanding as husband Tracy is old school. When Poitiers's parents arrive, the discussion comes to a head, and like Hepburn, Poitiers's soft spoken mother (Beah Richards) is more open to the idea than Poitiers's frightened father (Roy Glenn) who is old fashioned elegance and proud, but locked in old ideals.Isabel Sanford, as Tracy and Hepburn's housekeeper, represents the outsiders point of view from the black angle, while Virginia Christine is the uppity white person's point of view, deliciously told off by Hepburn. Grwsr moments in the script often make thus feel too "plotted" in every deal, with few awkward moments to represent the real life. But certain moments, such each of the major character's individual speeches (highlighted by Richards and Tracy's climactic viewpoints) are each brilliant in their own way. It's emotional to watch Hepburn and Tracy working together for the very last time, so being manipulated by the sentimentality can take over the soul while watching it. Still, as directed by the legendary Stanley Kramer, it comes out to be an important historical document on race relations, although in some aspects, it seems quite dated.

If you don't like this movie you are without class, plain and simple. This movie is simply divine.  This movie was made over thirtyyears ago and addresses an issue (bi-racial marriages) that isstill taboo in today's culture.  It's sad that we're moving that slowly. The movie is preachy towards the end for a reason...society needsto be preached to!  And nobody's listening.  People can still beignoramuses, it's like half the country is one gigantic ArchieBunker.  This movie faces that fact before most of the media did. And god bless them.  On top of that, they had Sidney Poitier, who tome is underrated and as charming and as debonair as CaryGrant, Katherine Hepburn, and Spencer Tracy.  Who could ask formore?  I wish I was coming to dinner!

reviews.review_title: An excellent film with a strong idea but some serious flaws...
reviews.content: The movie could easily be looked upon as a documentary today of how people reacted to inner racial relationships. A white person dating or marrying a black person is not shocking at all in today's society as it was thirty short years ago, and if the movie were to be made to today with the same script (updates here and there), it would be a pretty silly looking film.I do have a major problem with the movie though, and that is the script gives the Sidney Poitier no character flaws at all, he is the perfect gentleman with an education and is basically a good humanitarian. Nothing wrong with that, but I felt the script was yearning for my acceptance of this character by glorifying him as a saint, and not a human being. Wouldn't the script have been more challenging if Poitier was the manager of a shop and liked to kick back and relax every now and than? Why must he be this prestige doctor with credentials a mile long? I think a real challenge would have been to make him more relatable to people by making him simpler and not superman. Same thing goes to the Spencer Tracey and Katharine Hepburn characters, why are they living in a huge house and are so important? Couldn't they to have been written with a more simple tone so people could relate to them as people, and not just the situation? More people with modest incomes and simple lives will more likely watch the movie, since not everyone is a well to do citizen.But that aside the performances are extraordinary and the dominating theme that love conquers any challenges that arise out of life is inspirational. The love and commitment that exist between Poitier and Katharine Houghton is wonderful all the way through, they act like to kids in a candy store when they are onscreen together and I think that just binds their relationship tighter. I think it was wise to have them not threat over the life their children will face in the future was also a good step in the script, because two people in love are always ready to face anything head on. Katharine Hepburn is always glorious in her performances, and though she was not worthy of an Oscar win for this one (Anne Brancroft or Faye Dunaway should have been one of the winners that year), she still shines bright, especially since she is once again sharing the screen with her long time love, Spencer Tracey, in his final film performance.

Guess Who's Coming to Dinner is playfully teasing and provocative title. It has been riffed many times since even in a science fiction film such as Star Trek VI when the Klingons arrive to eat.The film has dated, the groovy dancing by the delivery boy and the housekeeper's daughter is laughable and the title song seems unsuited at times when it mingles with the film's score.Still director Stanley Kramer tackles the issue of forbidden love by casting Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn who had their own ongoing forbidden love affair spanning several decades.They play the wealthy liberal, open minded parents of Joanna Drayton (Katharine Houghton) who arrives early from a Hawaiian holiday by bringing her new fiancé after a whirlwind romance to introduce to her parents, John Prentice (Sidney Poitier) a widowed, black doctor.The issue is will they accept him and give the marriage their approval. The parents are flabbergasted and shocked. The local Catholic priest (a golfing buddy) drops in and is surprisingly more supportive of the union. Their black housekeeper thinks John Prentice is trying to get above his station.Tensions mount when John's working class family fly in for dinner with the Drayton and they get to hear the news of their son's engagement for the first time and they have concerns over an interracial marriage (still illegal in some states at that time.)The film at times can be clunky and John Prentice is just too good to be true. A top educated doctor working for the United Nations, although he has a rather testy scene with his retired postman father who counted the thousands of miles he walked in his working life so his son could have a good education and a better life.Maybe that is how the film had to present its subject matter at the time, a black doctor had to be better, more educated and nobler in order to be deemed by the audience to be suitable for this middle class white girl.

Guess Whos Coming To Dinner is a great film filled with humor and Spencer Tracy does not disappoint, as always. Overall an excellent film with a great message. The film deals with an "elephant in the room" situation where interracial marriage may seem frown upon to some but not others. Director Stanley Kramer does a fantastic job with this film and his ability to grab the audience in such a way is perfect. I felt that a few scenes did not seem to fit into the story and could have run smoother if left out but still a great film. Katherine Hepburn also does a great job and her character is priceless. The facial expressions Hepburn uses really makes the film fun. Great film and worth watching.

reviews.review_title: An Interracial trying to explain their upcomimg marriage to their parents over dinner.
reviews.content: This was a very good film. The color was beautiful and rich. The acting was excellent, the actors really sucked you into the plot and made you either love them, hate them, or just wanted to talk them out of decisions. They made the film very funny and also very emotional. Speaking of plot, it was a very thought out story line. It was good because it kept you wanting to keep watching to see what happened. It was very strong themed, too. It had such a cultural significance to how much trouble interracial couples have especially in this time period. On the other hand, though, it also showed that regardless of color, you should be with someone who loves you as much as you love them and everything else shouldn't matter. The camera-work was great, too, it didn't just stick to the couple, the camera moved with the other characters so you got to have multiple perspectives. A very good movie, overall.

I have to say I had my doubts about this movie. I had heard it was dated, boring, and slow from several different sources, but I decided to see it anyway, since it's such a classic. It turns out that it deserves its classic status, and it confirms the fact that Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy were two very fine actors.This movie could have very well been very bad, given the subject's tendency to melodrama, but the actors create characters so real that the inherent melodrama comes across as real drama. They create moments that struck me as both touching and very true, and kept me engaged in the tightrope that is this movie's plot. There are times when my eyes began welling up with tears at the truth in some of the lines, because it was poignant; and there are others where I laughed at the truth in some of the lines, because it was ironic. Stanley Kramer created a movie that touches on many different issues, and it always feels like he's just this side of cheesy schmaltz, but somehow the movie succeeds anyway. You can tell Kramer and his actors are walking a fine line here, but they're always on the right side.I like this movie. Oh, it's not perfect. There are definite and obvious flaws, but the fact that it moved me and that I believed every moment of it outweighs those flaws.

This film was released in 1967, the year I graduated from college, and during the time when segregation was being addressed all across the country. I saw it quite a few years ago and had the opportunity to see it again recently. It was done very gingerly, and making sure to point out that the couple had not experimented yet with sex in their brief romantic relationship.The key characters are Sidney Poitier as 37-yr-old physician John Prentice. He had been married and had one child but both his wife and child were killed a few years back in an accident. The character was written with almost perfect qualities, educated at the best institutions and doing volunteer medicine in third-world setting. The girl was Katharine Houghton (incidentally Hepburn's niece) as 23-yr-old Joey. She and John met in Hawaii just 10 days earlier and fell in love quickly. He is on his way to Geneva and stopped off in San Francisco with Joey to meet her parents. Most of the movie takes place in the family home, a beautiful place with a nice view of San Francisco Bay. Dad is a wealthy newspaper man.Dad is Spencer Tracy as Matt Drayton and his wife is Katharine Hepburn as Christina Drayton. A key figure also is Cecil Kellaway as family friend Monsignor Ryan. Naturally the parents were surprised and shocked when their daughter brought home a black man, even though both parents were liberals and often spoke in favor of equal rights and the ending of racial discrimination. What this fictional story wants to show is how difficult it is to accept this kind of diversity when it hits home at your own doorstep.And, when the Prentice parents came over from Los Angeles to meet everyone they were equally shocked. The title of this movie actually refers to the black parents coming to dinner. So the movie plays out with just about every combination of two of the 7 people discussing the pros and cons of the issue, fully realizing that the two single people are adults and ultimately will make their own decisions. But it is always nice to have all family members on-board and happy.The movie also is careful to make this two-way, not just a white family accepting a black son-in-law, but also the difficulty of a black family accepting a white daughter-in-law.This is a classic movie, not everyone will enjoy it, but it has great actors and tells an important story.

reviews.review_title: Great actors, telling a story of tolerance which seemed unlikely to me
reviews.content: This was an icon for the 60'. Mom, dad, grown daughter who got married with a guy her folks never met and whom she met 10 days ago and Poitier. There seemed to be a problem with the fact she's pink. The brown maid and brown in-law don't agree while mom and dad are getting used to the idea he's brown-skinned and sexy. Is it really what it was like in the US to be pink during the 60'? I never felt discriminated against and am as pink as can be.Nobody talked about the fact they married so fast. How come? Any dad would have objected to that.

reviews.review_title: Well-made film with timeless issues, but could have been better...
reviews.content: The most appealing aspect of this film is its overt, shameless portrayal of an issue that was completely and utterly taboo at the time of its release...interracial marriage; however, the film itself is only moderately entertaining.Spencer Tracy's performance was very good, especially when considering the complexities of his character (a liberal journalist who finds himself resenting the fact that his own daughter plans to marry someone of another race), and there were a few other notable performances (I especially liked Monsignor Ryan, played by Cecil Kellaway). The writing was one of the stronger aspects of the film as well, mostly because of the utter straightforwardness about a topic that would make many Americans in 1967 cringe. By showing on screen the shock that each family member received when initially aware of the marriage allowed for an equally shocking effect on the audience, and the reactions seen on screen were probably similar to those of many Americans at the time (and, unfortunately today as well).By having the Prentice family over for dinner at the end, the families are forced to look beyond whatever prejudices they might have and interact with people that are virtually foreign to them. In this sense, the movie carries a great message with it...and this message is still very applicable to today's society.The biggest problem with this film was the believability of the issue. Due to Katharine Houghton's (Joey's) bubbly, overacted performance, it was impossible for me to believe that these two were actually as deeply in love as they said, especially when you consider the fact that they have only known each other for 2 weeks. In addition, I thought the "forced" nature of the necessity for approval from the parents was completely unrealistic. In essence, some of the major plot points and details are flawed, keeping a movie that could have been great just so-so. Nonetheless, it is worth watching at least once, especially if historic context of the film is considered.

reviews.review_title: "Just two people with a pigment problem"
reviews.content: This movie does a great job at showing the hardships of interracial relations, while having comedy and romance intertwined. John has this little smirk on his face when he makes comments to her mother about their differences. This brings in comic relief to a somewhat serious and uncomfortable situation. Her mother is almost visibly shaking with anger. Mrs. Drayton's eyes are watered up as if she could not believe her eyes. Joey is somewhat naive and thinks that her parents will not have a negative reaction towards their inter-racial dating. It is funny how excited her parents are to meet a doctor. They were not expected him to be an African American. This shows stereo-typing in which everyone assumed a doctor to be a white man. John's family when talking to their son seems to be a lot more grounded on the topic although both families are upset. Chemistry and love can be shared amongst people of different races. That is what this couple show. Throughout the film her mother starts to smile at the idea that her daughter has fallen in love. Mrs. Drayton's body language and actions are much more warmed up to the idea as the film progresses. It may have taken her father longer but he does realize that their love is genuine despite their "pigment problem". Just like in time, people only need to get used to the change before they can accept it.

All of the characters have such great chemistry together and really play of each others energy. The movie address's a very important topic and racial issue of the time. Even though black people were finally respected in the community, integrated couples were still not accepted. People were expected to stay within their race. This movie does a great job representing what would happen if a wealthy white girl brought home a very smart respected doctor that she was going to marry. It was really interesting to watch how each member of the families react to the news. Surprisingly not boring considering that most of it takes place in a house. Very good movie.

The film Guess Who's Coming to Dinner by Stanely Kramer was quite ground breaking and very dramatic. With the film starting we follow the main character Dr. John Prentice. We see him start on a plane and land in San Francisco. What makes this film controversial is that John is African American and when he arrives in SF he meets up with his very recent girlfriend (Joey Drayton), who is white. The plan is that they want to get married right away. When Joey's parents discover it they are quite unready for their daughter to get married so quickly. Of course race is a factor, because at the time it would be breaking the social norms. But, the parents later agree and same for John's parents. The cinematography in the film is quite alright, but just about how I'd expect it to be in a film that basically takes place in a home. The lighting is very good always seems like it's changing especially throughout the day at the home. The editing is natural with no weird cuts or anything. The film ended on a great note showing what new cinema was going to be in the near future. Breaking away from the old generation's ideology and forming a new one. This film is a great example of that. All around I think a 7 is quite suitable for this film

reviews.review_title: Still Relevant All These Years Later
reviews.content: Being raised in a different generation than when this film takes place, it seems almost barbaric to see such a divide between races. Unfortunately, this was true, and in some cases, is still true today. he film deals with the ordeal of a black man marrying a white woman. Although the film was primarily a drama, I found a lot of comedy in some of the quick comebacks from the characters. Another element I found was some unintended racism. I felt a lot of the plot revolved around the unintentional racism, rather than the perceived threat from the public about an interracial marriage. the one great piece of irony about this film comes from a scene about the potential children, and how one might become the President of the United States. i will leave that research to you, but the irony was not lost on my end. In closing, RIP Spencer Tracy, because the speech at the end is so heartfelt that I almost cried. Thank you for such an excellent experience.

reviews.review_title: Not as impacting as it would have been in 1967, but it's fairly even-handed approach is a plus despite being dated, repetitive and slow paced at times
reviews.content: After meeting in Hawaii Joey Drayton and Dr John Prentice fly back to San Francisco so that John can meet Joey's parents. Joey (a white woman) is nervous about introducing John (a black man who she intends to marry) to her white parents. In order to restore some balance, Joey invites John's parents to her parents for dinner, but John's parents believe that Joey is a black woman. John and Joey are deeply in love (despite only meeting 10 days prior) and must convince their respective and somewhat sceptical parents that they are right for each other despite being from different ethnic backgrounds...One thing that's refreshing about Guess Who's Coming To Dinner is the way that the story unfolds; it would have been very easy (particularly given the era the film was made) for this film to be a one-sided pro-white film which to be honest wouldn't have been particularly pleasant to watch nor would it have been particularly insightful. The film is much more balanced and although Joey's parents aren't totally sold on the idea of their daughter marrying a black man it seems to be more out of concern of how society will react to them being a married couple (the prejudice that they are likely to encounter day in and day out will be tough going for them) so indirectly this could be interpreted as parents looking out for their child's welfare.Another thing that is interesting about this film is that the black maid seems to more against the idea of John marrying a white woman than anyone else; I suspect that this is because she has been a servant to rich white folk for a long time and perhaps feels that black people are inferior to white people and cannot accept the idea of an articulate, educated black man being superior to her - that's just my thought anyway.Whilst I mostly enjoyed Guess Who's Coming To Dinner it has to be said that it is far from a perfect film; as I've already mentioned the concept is a little dated now (although sadly racism is still a problem across the world so it isn't entirely irrelevant even in 2021). The direction is sluggish and I found the film to be a little repetitive; it seemed to just go round in circles covering the same ground and only really stepped up a gear when John's parents arrive.Spencer Tracy's speech at the end was quite something though and it's hard not to be a little moved by it - even if it was a little jarring when you look at everything that preceded it. Still many films focusing on race that have followed this film have been heavy-handed, one-sided and preachy and thankfully Guess Who's Coming To Dinner for the most part doesn't fall into those traps which is impressive considering it was made in the 1960's. It's worth a look, but it's not a film whose praises I would sing from the rooftops - it's reputation is a tad flattering if you ask me.

Guess Whos's Coming to Dinner (1967) directed by Stanley Kramer, is an excellent film that speaks about the message of racial discrimination and acceptance. The film is about a woman named Joey and her relationship with Dr. John Prentice, played by Sidney Poitier. This relationship is interesting because the two are interracial, this was different back during this time period. The film is great as it showcases the love between the two characters, and the acting is good too. Sidney Poitier is good here, almost as good as when he was in A Raisin in the Sun (1961). The film is relatable, to me and many others as I am biracial. The film is truly one to watch, and has an interesting theme. Overall, Guess Who's Coming to Dinner (1967), gets a 7 out of 10.

Guess Who's Coming to Dinner is so-so in my opinion, at least if you only look at the technical elements and not the plot. Everything seems entirely straightforward, with no particularly interesting camera angles or fancy lighting schemes or interesting moments of sound that went on for an extended period of time or seemed as though they were planned, as far as I can remember. I think what makes the movie so interesting is that it is so normal in every way, that it speaks to the turmoil that ripples though the plot. The main characters, an interracial couple, are the epitome of a normal couple that is happy and in love, but chaos and confusion and upset is all around them in very much the same way. What makes it so interesting is that the plot and technical elements mirror each other. Great messages that really hit home, having a mother who went through very much the same thing in the early '70s. Really touching, would watch again and recommend.

This movie is one of the greatest films ever made it had all the elements that an average movie lover would want; comedy, sadness,a little hatred, and of course happiness and joy. The acting was great, the actors played their roles to the point that it feels as though it really happened to them. The maid was funny yet at the same time really annoying because she took the side of keeping the two "races" separate throughout a majority of the film. The facial expressions on the faces of the parents on both sides was absolutely priceless it was comedic yet believable as if they were not acting, which only reiterate my comment earlier saying that the acting was great. This movie is a must watch.

reviews.review_title: Tracy's Swansong has So-So Plot, but Great Story Behind it...
reviews.content: GUESS WHO'S COMING TO DINNER might have been daring, in terms of 1967 mores, in tackling a 'taboo' (interracial marriages), but director Stanley Kramer, long a champion of social issues, actually made this film to give dying friend Spencer Tracy an on screen 'Last Hurrah', resulting in a script that was more a showcase for the actors than a truly honest examination of the issue (the leads are all brilliant and noble and 'too good to be true', thus making any question of whether Tracy would give his blessing to his daughter marrying doctor Sidney Poitier ridiculously easy to predict). That William Rose won an Oscar for his simplistic screenplay is NOT one of the Academy's finer moments, but in terms of performance, Spencer Tracy would prove, one last time, why he was America's finest film actor.The backstory of the film is fascinating; by 1960, Tracy's health had become so poor, after a lifetime of alcohol abuse, that studios were unwilling to hire him. Stanley Kramer stepped in, and courageously cast the actor in INHERIT THE WIND, JUDGMENT IN NUREMBERG, and, finally, in IT'S A MAD, MAD, MAD, MAD WORLD. Sadly, Tracy's deteriorating condition was painfully obvious in the 1963 comedy, and he soon suffered a series of health setbacks that left him nearly bedridden. Katharine Hepburn put her own career on hold to nurse the ailing actor, with whom she'd had a relationship for over twenty years, and she watched as the enforced inactivity slowly killed him. Going to Kramer, the pair worked out a scheme to get Tracy back on his feet and acting again, knowing that while the effort might kill him, it would let him 'go out' in the manner he preferred. Kramer visited the ailing actor with the script for GUESS WHO'S COMING TO DINNER, explaining how his part could be filmed with a minimum of risk to his health, with his beloved 'Kate' at his side, and her niece, Katharine Houghton, making her film debut...and that he had already cast Sidney Poitier, the greatest black actor in Hollywood, to co-star. He then visited Poitier, showed him the script, and told him he'd already gotten Tracy and Hepburn to commit to the project! The ruse worked, with both Tracy and Poitier agreeing to make the film.There was still a last hurtle to cross; no insurance company would underwrite a film with Tracy, because of his health. Kramer and Hepburn worked out an agreement, that both would sacrifice their salaries, if Tracy died during the production. The underwriters agreed to those terms, and filming began.It was a happy, if careful, 'shoot', with Tracy's biggest scenes, including the long 'testimonial' speech the film is best known for, shot first. At the completion of his last scene filmed (when he and Hepburn order ice cream, in their car), cast and crew gave the actor a standing ovation, and Tracy was visibly moved. He would pass away just days later, but Hepburn was right; he went out the way he wanted to, on film.Both Tracy and Hepburn were nominated for Oscars for the film; while his was certainly deserved, her role wasn't really that large or demanding. Yet on Oscar night, she won the statuette, which she graciously accepted as being for 'both' of them. A year later, she'd match Tracy's 'back-to-back' Oscar achievement, by winning for her brilliant performance as Eleanor, in THE LION IN WINTER.GUESS WHO'S COMING TO DINNER is not a great movie, and it has not stood the test of time nearly as well as Tracy and Hepburn's other pairings. But as a last opportunity to see Spencer Tracy, it shouldn't be missed, and Stanley Kramer and Katharine Hepburn deserve praise for their courage in making this come to pass!

I have often heard of Guess Who's Coming To Dinner? but never got around to renting it. Fortunately, I happened to view this film, by chance, on television. My eyes were glued to the screen right from the start. I don't doubt that some of the dialogue and situations are dated but that isn't what matters. What is important is that the film has a way of making the viewer challenge their own thoughts about inter-racial marriage. I am from New Zealand and there is not such a big deal about inter-racial partnerships but since my arrival in the USA, I have learned about the history of the many races that call this country home. This film best represents a time when a nation was slowly awakening to a basic human right; that all races should be equal. At first, Katharine Houghton's Joanna seems naive and too perky but by the end of the film, I realised that that is her personality make-up and I feel that she isn't a light-weight, but adds a different perspective and balance to the other characters. One can see why Sidney Poitier's John Prentice has fallen for this bright, optimistic and determined lady. Beah Richards and Roy Glenn do a wonderful job of playing the worried parents of Sidney Poitier. Their statements about inter-racial love were delivered honestly and with integrity, not with the prejudice, I feel, that the American public of the time would have felt. Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracey's portrayals of Joanna's parents' are fantastic. They are honest, torn, complex and handled with dignity. I am now most pleased that Katharine Hepburn won the Best Actress Academy Award for this performance. However, I truly believe that the film would not have been as successful if it wasn't for the focal character played by the intelligent, magnetic and graceful Sidney Poitier. Every word he spoke was filled with reason, fear, love and hope. The multiple facets of this character are portrayed with pure class. There were many times during the viewing of this film where I was genuinely on the verge of tears. This film is a thought-provoking catalyst for the equality of all human beings not only in America, but also in the world. Guess Who's Coming To Dinner? is a universal beacon of hope for racial equality and cultural understanding.

reviews.review_title: .............and the winner is Katharine Hepburn in Guess Who's Coming To Dinner
reviews.content: Director Stanley Kramer and Spencer Tracy had an un official partnership with Inherit The Wind, Judgement At Nuremberg, It's A Mad Mad Mad World and this classic film. We all know the back story: Mr Tracy was ill and Columbia was nervous about the film so Kramer and Katharine Hepburn put their fees in escrow so the film could be made The subject matter was stunning when the film was made and it was very brave on Columbia's part to finance the film. Sidney Poitier and Katharine Houghton are fine but it is the two legendary stars Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy who give impeccable and indelible performances. Spencer Tracy's great speech at the end of the film is a landmark of acting. Had Mr Tracy lived I predict Spencer Tracy would have won his 3rd Oscar, Ms Hepburn did win the Oscar and some may question the selection but not here. Ms Hepburn's quiet and eloquent performance speaks volumes, and does more here with her eyes than some actresses do with a 5 page script speech. How Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn respected and loved each other! Spencer Tracy died a superstar of the first rank with first billing, and one would have to go to his early films in the 30's where Tracy was not first billed. A Star, An Actor, A Man! Decades after his Death to many including Me he is the finest actor of the silver screen.

Timely in 1967, and even more timely now. Just watched it again tonight, and am simply amazed at how relevant the overall message still is. Amazing, amazing cast. Sidney Poitier (so handsome) and Katherine Houghton (so beautiful) are absolutely tremendous as the two lovers. Katherine Hepburn, Spencer Tracy, Roy Glenn and Beah Richards as their parents shine. Cecil Kellaway as Monsignor Ryan is pure delight, and
so is Isabel Sanford as Tillie. Everyone is believable, the way they interact, the facial expressions --- so many pure, simple moments. I love this movie. Beah Richards and Spencer Tracy get me crying every time at the end of the movie...they both deliver very raw, emotional speeches...very powerful. Katherine Hepburn of course is just the perfect mother.....an electrifying, completely real performance.....her scene with Virginia Christine/Hilary at the house is simply one of my all-time favorites. All of the performances come off as 100% genuine, and there are many funny moments within all the drama.The writers were so smart to script/create the characters the way they did. Many people have said to me, "Well, if they had made John Prentice a cook or dishwasher at a restaurant, it would have been a different story". Yes, yes it would have. And that's exactly the reason why they created him as such --- he's the perfect man, everything from gorgeous, good-looks, down to his education and behavior. And same with Joey Drayton --- comes from a well-to-do family and is stunning and not a snob. Had they made either one different, it would have given the parents on either side to object, saying, "Well, Joey, Mr. Prentice is just a dishwasher.... are you sure he's not just after your money?", or "John, Joey is from a middle-class family, are you sure you're not just hung up on her looks, and that she's not a gold-digger trying to hook her claws into any doctor that's available?" By creating the two lovers the way the writers did --- John being an extremely successful, handsome doctor and Joey coming from a very well-established family -- there really is no other reason to object, unless you have an issue with the other's race, which both sides did. It made each of the parents have to self-examine themselves internally, to see why they felt the way that they did, as their son/daughter fell in love with truly the perfect person. The mothers on both sides knew the truth, and knew that true love would conquer all, and it did....happily so.But, this 59 year old white male found himself blubbering like a 10 year old girl at the end of the movie this time, more so than usual.....not just because it's beautifully made, not just because of it's message, but because I sat there, thinking, "Wow, it's been almost 55 years since this was made, and it seems like our country has evolved backwards, not moved forward"....and it's very, very disconcerting to say the least, and extremely sad and depressing. If you haven't seen this film, or it's been a while, do yourself a favor and watch it.....truly a valentine to the world from Stanley Kramer and everyone involved, with a very important message. Watching it again renews hope, so pass it on. Love prevails.

I just saw "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner" for the first time. I'm a major movie buff, but somehow had never caught this film in its entirety before. I finally decided to see it.Besides the fact that I was embarrassed to be subjected to the scene with the delivery guy be-bopping and trying to represent the hipster generation, and besides the fact that it was a contrived situation to have a fabulously wealthy family whose happiness was never truly put to the test, I found myself quite moved by the powerful final performance of Spencer Tracy. His should have been the academy award performance of 1967. His emotion was real, and every word of his final speech was as relevant today as it was 38 years ago. And even though he was dying while making the film it was never apparent...his energy and conviction were genuine, and quite moving.Other performances ranged from excellent to possibly overdone, but maybe some of them were reflective of the times. Hepburn's performance was strong, as the academy also noticed that year. However, I think Poitier's performance might have been a bit overstated. Somehow, I've never completely bought into his performances...I think it's just the way he projects himself that makes him seem a little over the top to me. Nonetheless, he generally acquitted himself well and displayed no less than a passion and conviction for the material. The daughter (Hepburn's real-life niece) came off a bit too bubbly and energetic, I think, but she was acceptable. Isabel Sanford had a line that made me cringe...she actually states to Poitier's character her disdain for his attempting to marry ABOVE himself! That floored me that a member of her own race would make such a self-demeaning statement. Were attitudes really like that in '67? The scene with the idiot delivery guy should be excised from the film. It adds no comedy element, and only serves to frighten us into believing that once society must have thought that it was cool for kids to act this way.For the final speech alone, this movie gets a 7 out of 10 from me.

A little outdated, but unfortunately not nearly outdated enough. Some of the language is painfully antiquated, but the issue it tackles seems very much still with us.I like the fact that Joey's parents were actually liberals. Watching them confronted with a challenge to their principles made it far more interesting than simply having them be out and out bigots.I found the housemaid to be one of the most old fashioned aspects of the movie and really didn't enjoy that role.All round solid acting and great casting.Better than expected.

This movie was an interesting look back at a time when color of your skin meant more than ANYTHING else about you. of course, this is not a completely foreign concept today, but I think most people would agree that if a parent met someone as upstanding as John they would be throwing a party. I really enjoyed how much the film allowed you to sit with these ideas and hear it from all of the sides. It wasn't rushed, and it was more important to hear from these characters than to wow the audience with effects and plot twists. When we see that the contempt at the idea of an interracial marriage is not so one sided, we realize just how deep the institution of racism goes and the message of the film becomes even more essential. The shape of the movie reminded me a lot of The Birdcage(La Cage Aux Folles), though I wonder if that is mere coincidence given that it was a French play before it ever made it to The United States.Some of the acting was a little stale for my taste, but the message is strong and one that should continue to be discussed.

Yes, the screenplay is contrived & some of the "set pieces" are too stagey, but the actors in this film all triumph (with the clear exception of Katherine Houghton who's perky enough, but seems awfully light-weight in this company).Beah Richards is exceptionally fine as Sidney Poitier's mother & her delivery in her critical speech is dead on.  It's easy to understand why hers are the words that open Tracy's mind.  When he says "I'll be damned!" -- what a wonderful moment!  The Academy thought so too.  She remains one of the few black actresses nominated for an Oscar.  (She should have been nominated for BELOVED as well, but alas.)In the end, though, this film will always be remembered as Hepburn & Tracy's last joint on-screen appearance.  Tracy died soon after the film was complete.  They both seem to know this & the shots of them looking at each other are filled with palpable love & tenderness.Jan @ films42.com

This movie does a very good job at highlighting the troubles of interracial couples during the 60's. The movie is more elegant rather than harsh about the subject and it makes it much easier to watch the movie and enjoy it while still understanding the message behind it. The actors are amazing in their roles and it definitely was produced during a touchy time. Movies like this weren't widely spread in the 60's, especially in the south, so it really stands apart from others. Many refused to even watch it, but I think this movie definitely deserves a watch, especially during the times we are in right now.

The fact that this film, almost 50 years old, is still culturally relevant is depressing. Films of this nature are supposed to help progress society into being more open-minded and force future generations to work in order to relate. It's truly unfortunate for everybody living, that modern audiences can watch Guess Who's Coming to Dinner and be capable of relating to it. I'm a big fan of single-setting films. Though Guess Who does venture off into a few other locations, a majority of it takes place at the home of the (Joey) Drayton's. This isolation puts the entire films focus on the relationship. Films of this nature don't rely on clever editing tricks or plot devices; it's all dialog and character development. I enjoyed the complex nature of each character's concerns and how despite the ending being predictable, I was very interested in seeing how each character would evolve by the film's end. It's fair to say the film's topic is prime for a remake with a more contemporary plot. (Ie: Gay Marriage / Gay Interracial marriage) though I'd be concerned it would receive the necessary attention to prevent it from being a cash grab and not a true attempt at social commentary.

I was very unfamiliar with the film "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner", I found it to be very interesting throughout the movie, the beginning set the tone for a very cheerful film with the music being played. I very much liked the fact that an issue like this was brought up in this time period, people could watch and learn what most families deal with in issues that they face. The setting definitely had a nice touch, the views and gardens of the home where most of the film took place was gorgeous. I also loved the fact that it taught a lesson, being if you as parents teach your child beliefs while growing up they carry on with them and you can't be surprised when they actually end up in a situation that you let them believe in. I kind of knew throughout the whole film what was going to happen, the end did not come to a shock to me. Overall I thought the storyline and issue brought into the movie was good. Setting was great as well as photography and camera working capturing closeups of important conversations throughout the film.

reviews.review_title: Doesn't live up to Poitier's performance
reviews.content: Having not been alive at the time this movie was released, I wonder what the reaction was to all the preaching in this movie. No doubt it said things that American society needed to hear in the 1960s, but to a modern audience it sounds almost quaint. Tracy's speech at the end, for example, is not easy to sit through, but it's not just because of the rationalizations he goes through, it's just not a good scene. You might as well fast forward to this point if you want to know what the makers of the movie thought the message is supposed to be. The problem with this is that there are many layers and nuances in the first 90 minutes that are simply ignored in the final 20 (or so) minutes. The tidy package that Tracy's speech is supposed to wrap up doesn't, in fact, exist. It's as if the screenplay at this point is taken up years after the original was written and interpreted by the same people who came up with the adolescent documentaries of the 40s and 50s.The best performance comes from Beah Richards as Poitier's mother, who gives a nice speech about what love means. Poitier is good also as he tries to tread the line between a modest nice guy and a melancholy saint. I just wish this movie had lived up to his intensity and complexity.

This 1967 drama has some fans over the years. However it was a phoney attempt at racial recnciliation. The young woman was obviously too young and immature to be love interest of Dr Prentiss, a black physician. She acted like a air-headed the entire movie, and hardly was there chemistry between her and the male lead. The attempt at playfulness was like father-daughter. Now the mother, Katherine Hepburn who was expectedly shocked when her daughter brought me a black man (this is 1967). But all of that shock lasted but 5 minutes. After that the hollywood liberal became evident. Spencer Tracy was barely a tad more hesitant before giving in. Another thing wrong - this is the fault of infantile writers: the black man in question had to be Yale professor of medicine, and won honors internationally for his work in the WHO. A black man had to have these credentials to be palatable to white society ? What if he was only a sales executive ? No, he wouldnt have been good enough. The most interesting relationship was the dynamic between the black guest and the black maid. And what was the animosity between him and his father who also came to dinner ?This film was lauded for its sensitive subject in that era, but did not exhibit the intelligence it deserves.

reviews.review_title: Black people who conform in ways we deem acceptable are easy to...accept
reviews.content: The two big, moralizing speeches in this movie capture my main issue overall. Poitier's speech to his father is a powerful and unique argument against bigotry. Tracy's ending speech, on the other hand, is just basic white-guy, virtue-signaling self-righteousness. While this movie may have been progressive in '67, it often just comes off as retrograde white neoliberalism now. Harsh? Maybe. It's certainly engulfing & wonderfully performed, but something about it doesn't sit right anymore.

Imagine if you will the social climate in 1967 San Francisco. The Civil Rights act was in effect but society was still wavering on total acceptance of 'civil rights'. Guess Who's Coming to Dinner tested society in its acceptance of true 'civil rights'. Spencer Tracy (Matt Drayton) and Katharine Hepburn (Christina Drayton)were exceptional and convincing as a modern, liberal accepting couple. This is tested when their daughter Joanna Drayton (Katharine Houghton) arrives home with her fiancé, Dr. John Prentice (Sidney Poitier). The Drayton's liberal beliefs are tested as their future son-in-law is a Negro (term used in film). Vital to the settings moral attitude of the 'church', Monsignor Ryan (Cecil Ryan) shows is uplifting support for the Joanna and John. Matt Drayton is not as supportive as his wife Christina. She sees the romance he only sees problems for their future. Then, when the Drayton's meet the Prentices the feelings are mutual. But nothing the parents say is going to stop Joanna as she is either oblivious or just doesn't care about any prejudices they may face. The ideas and social controversy of this film is unfortunately still evident in our modern society. The film also brought into play the long time controversial relationship between Hepburn and Tracy. In Tracy's final speech about relationships and what's important you could feel his emotion and can tell it came from his own heart and when he looks at Katharine she tears up. I could feel the emotion and love between them. The camera angles are detrimental in capturing the emotions and reactions in each scene of each character. When Christina is sitting out on the patio with Joanna and John the camera zooming in on her face focus' us on her reaction as well as pulling the viewer into her character. Another example where the camera angle was so important was at the end when Matt is walking on the patio thinking about his decision concerning Joanna and John's relationship. He stops under the tree, camera zooms in close on his face only, this draws you into his emotions at that very moment, and then he says, "I'll be a son of a bitch", turns around and goes into the living room and delivers this wonderful speech about relationships and love. Absolutely breathtaking! This was the last wonderful performance by Spencer Tracy and the last film by the great duo of Tracy and Hepburn. Guess Who's Coming to Dinner is a classic and a must see film for all.

reviews.review_title: Controversial when released, but just as entertaining today.
reviews.content: Good film enters depths that have never been explored before, and Guess Who's Coming to Dinner does just that. Released in 1967, the film portrayed the then controversial topic of interracial marriage. The film takes a liberal standpoint throughout and portrays Dr. John Prentice (the colored gentleman) as the ideal perfect man. Respectable, honorable and flawless, Sidney Poitier plays the character with such elegance and poise that any parent would want a partner like him for their child. Katharine Houghton (Katharine Hepburn's real life niece) plays Joanna Drayton, the lovely but naive interest to Dr. Prentice. The best performances however go to Spencer Tracy and Katherine Hepburn who play Joanna's parents. Both characters are complex and intriguing and the actors do a good job at portraying that even if it's just in facial expression. The writing is top notch and one of the movie's strongest points. Although it does not have the impact it had when first released, it can be seen why it's remained a classic over the years.

reviews.review_title: Guess Who Has A Fake Accent
reviews.content: This film was recently broadcast on a local station. Since I was only 4 when it was released, I had never seen it before, although I was familiar with the title and the overall premise which was considered controversial back then. So I decided to watch it. I figured a well known film with Sydney Poitier and Spencer Tracy trying to make a cultural point would be worth the time.But the believability failed on many levels. Spencer Tracy looked old enough to be the girl's grandfather rather than her father. All race issues aside, this couple wanted to get married and had known each other for less than 2 weeks. What was the point of the Monsignor Ryan character? He could have easily been written out without affecting the story at all.But the biggest problem is Hepburn. I'd think the real question on Prentice's parents mind wouldn't be, "Why is my son marrying a white girl?" Or, "why is my son marrying a girl he just met?" Or, "Why is there a Monsignor in the script?" Or even, "Why is Weezie working here?". The obvious question would be, "What country is your mom from and exactly what accent is that?".Back in the day, Sesame Street did a bit called, "one of thee things is not like the other". And while watching this film the question yells at you from the screen, "What country is this lady from?". Two American families, one with an American maid living in America... but Hepburn's fake accent throughout this film is like an eternal blaring cat pee stain on a hand woven rug. Bad enough her voice sounds like she sucked down a can of helium, but that accent is like finger nails on a chalk board. And, BTW, why does she keep shaking her head "no" all the time?

The classic tale of two people falling in love. Really weird that they're engaged after only knowing each other for ten days. Still, you have to appreciate the man and woman's undying love for each other. But that's a pretty big difference in their age. He's 37, she's 23. There was one scene I found funny; The girl's parents go to get ice-cream, and the dad orders what he thinks he got before, only to find out it's a different flavor. After his initial fussing, he decides he like it anyway. What was the point of complaining in the first place, then? I couldn't decide who the main antagonist was, the dads for not approving of the engagement, or the future husband, the source of the parents' discomfort? Still, great movie, great ending.

Originally I had seen the Ashton Kutcher and Bernie Mac remake, not actually realizing it was a remake of this 1967 film. Though in the original film the roles are reversed, the interracial marriage concept is the same. Though perhaps this film had more of an impact on society than the new one. I particularly liked this movie, despite many of the iffy things I have read about it. Sure, ten days of knowing each other and then jumping into marriage is slightly unrealistic, but it is not unheard of in our world. That being one of the biggest issues that people had with this film is a little shallow in my opinion. It's an important film that pushed social boundaries and even the liberal beliefs of the girl's parents. I did enjoy the story and the fact that the movie was filmed in color. Also the telling of the story was interesting, all in one evening and everything that lead up to it. I also really liked the characters, especially Joey and her child-like innocence in believing the good in everybody.

this movie really makes me wonder if the issues in the film are still as serious as they were back when it was made. obviously interracial couples were somewhat frowned upon for a few reasons then, but are they now? anyway it is a very intriguing film and even though it only takes place over the course of one day it keeps things very interesting and entertaining. i must give some credit to the actors too, i thought most of them did an amazing job given the somewhat controversial topic. and on top of it all they manage to make it a pretty funny movie. i must say i was pretty impressed and i would definitely recommend watching it for both the funny bits and racial issues/non-issues.

reviews.review_title: dated attitudes, but a timeless collaboration between two stars
reviews.content: The passage of several decades may have dimmed the controversy surrounding one of Hollywood's first interracial kisses, but in retrospect it was only the talent of its cast that made this groundbreaking comedy drama worth watching in the first place. The sometimes labored and over-earnest scenario gave movie legends Spencer Tracy and Katherine Hepburn a chance to share the screen one final time, and their rapport is so strong that when Tracy makes his climactic declaration of love to his wife and family ("I still have memories") he might have been speaking out of character directly to Kate Hepburn herself (he died just weeks later). Sidney Poitier displays his customary magnetic charm, but it would be impolite to dwell on the desperate '60s giddiness of his fiancé in the film, played (in a suspicious case of nepotic casting) by Hepburn's own niece.

The cast in this movie couldn't have been better. Ever since I've seen Sidney Poitier, I can't get enough of him. He really was that actor who inspired variety in Hollywood. The premise of the film is fantastic, although it was very controversial at the time. However movies that take risks are movies I can appreciate. I think some people today can still learn a valuable lesson from the strong message this film posses.

Definitely a movie not to be missed, "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner" is a great movie with a deep message that definitely still applies today in some households. Starring Spencer Tracy, Sidney Poitier, Katharine Hepburn and Katharine Houghton, "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner" is a story about a sweet, carefree and intelligent California girl, Joey,(Katharine Houghton) bringing home her colored friend (husband unbeknown to her parents at first,) John, (Sidney Poitier) to prove to him that her parents won't have a problem with him being a man of color as long as she is happy. You see both his and her parents struggle with the idea and yet both couples love their child more than anything, have taught their children to be accepting of others, and can see how in love the two are. It's a heart-filled story that's sure to move you in some way, and get you thinking about what's really important in life: love!

This is the kind of film that is really good as a time capsule, but doesn't really bode well as a good movie. I won't elaborate, because I think past posts have explained most things very well, thank you. But here are the problems:1. This film is about an issue. There is hardly any line of dialogue that doesn't deal with this couple's relationship and dealing with the reality in the real world. Yes, this issue is relevant today, but the issue presented here is hardly relevant, because the suitor is...2. Sydney Poitier! I mean, this guy is the man! Poitier never played a character more perfect than this, and usually, his characters are pretty perfect! He is a demi-God of all that is right with the world. A doctor who probably deserves the Noble Prize.Well, there are other things. But I won't sway too much on the negative. I did enjoy Spencer Tracy in this movie, and did find some moments funny. A film like this should be congratulated for putting an issue like this in our nation's conscience. Its just too bad it hasn't aged well.6/10

I loved this movie for many reasons but most importantly for the message of the movie and Spencer Tracy's moving speech at the end. As I believe all of us have been exposed to prejudice in one form or another this movie tackles a issue many parents have sometimes wondered about and sometimes faced, head on. What if my son/daughter wants to marry a white/black person. This movie addresses parents first reactions, second reactions and ultimate decisions when a black man wants the approval of his fiancé's white parents before getting married. Equally dismayed are his parents and in the space of 4 hours they need to come to a decision before the couple leaves for New York and then Switzerland. Love ultimately triumphs despite the prejudices the couple will face but you cannot help but cheering for them in the end and for the parents who were able to open their hearts to their future family. No surprise Sidney Poitier won an Oscar but be sure and have a box of tissues handy cause you'll need them.

reviews.review_title: Hepburn and Tracy.. need I say more?
reviews.content: Another wonderful movie from Hepburn and Tracy. They are just great in this film. Tracy's speech at the end just says it all. (esp. since he died not too long after) Also Poitier gives a strong, wonderful performance. One of the best scenes is when Poitier is talking to his father and he says "You think of yourself as a colored man. I think of myself as a man." My eyes filled up with tears when I heard that. This is a great movie and if you havent seen it, you should really give it a chance, it's a classic.

Labored, dated and dull, this movie has only a few things right about it: lovely bits of business between Tracy and Hepburn, the disdain of the "Negro" parents for their boy's infatuation with a vapid white girl.  Even in 1967 it was hopelessly out of date; today it is either offensive or camp. Still, it has its heart in the right place, and on its sleeve; one really wants to wish that the agony of race in America could be reduced to this sort of pleasant sitcom setup.

I found Guess Who's Coming to Dinner to be a very enjoyable film. The film tackled a very serious issue of the time and an issue that is still present to this day. The movie confronts the issue that people have with inter-racial relationships. It was also very refreshing to see a depiction of two people who were so in love and who didn't at all care about the other's race. This was able to really come across because of the quality of the acting. I thought Sidney Poitier's performance was great, like the majority of his performances are. The only problem that I had with the movie was the fact that prior to their engagement the couple had only known each other for a week or two, which just seemed like a bit of a stretch.

Truly an enjoyable and memorable picture made SO wonderful by Tracy and Hepburn's performances, Poitier is amazing, so it is a miracle that he fell in love with the simple minded air headed boring girl full of put on voices and put on faces. The maid and Poitier's parents performance are amazing. The father full of indignation and the mother filled with the joy of seeing her son so happy- just fantastic performances all around. If only Hepburn had not insisted on putting her talentless niece in the pivotal role of the daughter it would have been a perfect movie. Her wooden and mannequin-like moves and performance and conversation put one in mind of a 22nd century android. No feeling, no emotion, but moves and talks. How strange she never got another role! For Poitier to act INTERESTED in her, let alone in love should have won him an academy award. And PS- If she is only 20 years old, I would have to say she must have been a serious change of life baby for Ms. Hepburn, who are more grand parents age to Joey's 20 than parents.

I really enjoyed this film. It was the perfect blend of comedy and drama. There were some very funny moments yet some very serious moments and the actors had no problem naturally going from one to the other. Katharine Hepburn was marvelous. Her character really shined in this film. You could tell her character was uncomfortable at first with her daughter's relationship but you could also tell that she loved her daughter and really tried to support her. Spencer Tracy was also wonderful in this film. You could really see his character's internal struggle throughout the film. The entire message in the film about interracial couples was also wonderful especially considering when this film was made. I think everybody really needs to see this film because it so wonderfully shows so many different sides to one story and the good that can come from just opening up your mind and heart and accepting people for who they are and not how they look.

Guess Who's Coming to Dinner is an excellent film about society's growth and about dealing with change and facing up to our own fears and prejudices. This movie is timeless because the theme is timeless. People today still face the same troubles even almost 50 years after the film was made. I think the most impressive element of this movie is the dialogue, it is excellently written and beautifully spoken. Their languages clearly show each character's characteristics. I believe the angles and lighting were just right for this movie. There were close-ups throughout the movie made it very intimate which held true to the theme of the movie. The lighting made the movie feel a little more cheerful, as well. Although a little more action would have held my attention more, something to break up the monotony.

reviews.review_title: Review for Guess Who is Coming to Dinner
reviews.content: Guess Who is Coming to Dinner might have to be added to my favorites list; I can say that I truly enjoyed every aspect of this film. From the acting, directing, story line, and underlying message I can honestly say that that it was all impressive. Stanley Kramer made a bold move choosing to produce a movie that dealt with such controversial issues, but his risk was very worth taking. Civil rights were booming as African Americans were becoming to be seen as equal, well to majority, however they still dealt with everyday problems regardless of who they were or what they had accomplished in their life. Kramer did an excellent job illustrating that an African American man may be a prestigious person with an impressive background, but that is not going to stop anyone from judging him by his skin color. The love story is beautiful as well as it depicts two people falling in for each other for nothing else, and regardless of what any other person may say or feel they were confident in their love. Nothing is as remarkable as the ending though, as the two lovers are struggling with their parents approval Joey's father comes to the realization that is does not matter of John is black white yellow or purple, he Is the man her daughters loves and ultimately he wants her to be happy. Spencer Tracy's monologue at the end was breath taking as he speaks with such power and pure magnificence, not breaking character once as he brought real emotion to the movie and enforced the message that love knows no boundaries as it will conquer all in the end and it does not matter who it may be with because the true importance is finding love, that perfect soul mate, and not letting them go. I would absolutely recommend this movie as there is not one ounce of disappointment throughout this immaculate film.

reviews.review_title: Once again Hollywood cops out while patting itself on the back
reviews.content: This is the ultimate example of a film that should have been great but settled for safety, big box office, and mediocrity.  A pity.Consider the premise: It's the late sixties, a time of conflict, change and idealism.  A well-to-do San Francisco liberal couple find their commitment to their beliefs challenged and shaken to the very core by their daughter's sudden engagement to a black man.  There it is in a nutshell, and it's a beauty, rife with pitfalls.  It doesn't even hurt that the prospective bridegroom is a successful physician so that the girl's father (a judge) can't object that she's marrying beneath herself professionally.It's pretty much all downhill from there on.  Hollywood has to play it safe.Can't afford to offend the liberals out there in movieland.  Can't make them squirm in their seats in possible self-recognition as this couple are forced to reconcile their ideologies with an all-too-natural concern for their daughter's happiness.  The answer?  Cast Tracy and Hepburn!  Anyone who doubts for a moment how they're going to weather this situation or the conclusions they'll reach hasn't been paying attention.  And for the bridegroom?  Well let's play it safe all the way around and go with Sidney Poitier.  What the hey, George Wallace and Orval Faubus would probably pay him to marry their daughters!Sadly, Hollywood chose to portray itself as confronting a serious social issue rather than making a serious run at actually tackling the question head on.  To this day, 34 years later, I still wonder what elements Ivan Dixon (from "Hogan's Heroes"), say, would have brought to the Poitier role. And, just as a thought, how about Richard Widmark as the father?  The eventual outcome, I suspect, would not have been so predictable.And how about NOT ending the film with that smarmy "The Story of Love" playing endlessly as they all go in to dinner?  It's bad enough when a movie preaches, but when it preaches to the choir -- who already believe -- the result is . . .  a copout.

reviews.review_title: It's a classic and a classic it is...
reviews.content: This is movie history, portraying a decade in which African Americans got beaten up by police for simply demanding equal rights. There was still lots of segregation in the sixties and this movie epitomizes that era in which African Americans were still seen as inferior or a threat.It is kinda shocking nowadays to watch such a lovely picture about love, being solely concerned about which color the boyfriend has got.A flashback to an era of racism, compressed into a romantic picture with an absolute A-star listing that is still worthwhile watching because of the historic relevance of the story.

The film Guess Who's Coming to Dinner is a film with a theme that tackles the once frowned upon situation of bi-racial relationships, or moreover bi-racial marriage. Filmed in 1967, the director, Stanley Kramer, dared to touch on these issues during a very controversial period surrounding race and civil rights. One way he was able to take on the subject with phenomenal results was to involve some of the greatest actors of all time, Spencer Tracy as Matt Drayton, Katharine Hepburn as Christina Drayton and Sidney Poitier as Dr. John Wade Prentice.The story takes place over a 12 hour period and begins with Dr. Prentice, an older African American research physician, and Joey Drayton (Katharine Houghton), the daughter of a liberal newspaper owner and an open minded art gallery owner, arriving by plane from Hawaii where they had met just 10 days prior. It is apparent from the onset, or at least the cab ride, that they are involved in a relationship much more than mere friendship. Their plan is actually to marry within the next month, but first they want the approval of Joey's parents before the doctor's plane takes off that evening.During the next 10 hours, many reluctant characters are introduced including Tillie, played by Isabel Sanford, the maid that practically raised Joey. This helped to show the resistance on both sides of the racial divide, and gave clear objectivity to the point that it was not just a parental objection, but one not embraced by blacks or whites as groups. After Dr. Prentice's parents are also brought into the film, it is appears that the families are split on giving their blessing; men against women.One interesting point in the film that the director used ironically was a scene where Matt and Christina get ice cream so that Matt can have a "cooling off" period to collect his thoughts. Matt orders a flavor that he thought he knew, and after he tastes it he realizes he had not had the flavor before. After a few tastes and some complaining, he realizes that he really likes the new flavor and wants to remember it for the next time he comes in for ice cream. This scene appears to use the ice cream ironically as a reference to Matt's feelings toward Dr. Prentice. He thought he knew how he felt about race, he was open and liberal, yet when faced with it being presented in his own family his experience turns out to be somewhat bitter. However, after he finds out more about the prominent doctor, he cannot help but like him.The lighting and sound effects used in this film give the soft sense of a light romantic comedy while keeping the controversial plot intact. The story, although often a touchy subject matter, is kept to minimal offense by light hearted music, elegant and friendly atmosphere filled with educated characters easily portrayed with slight comedic relief.This influential and daring film proves to be a great entertainment experience that touches on a once sensitive subject and still has some relevance today. This is apparent in the sparingly re-made version some 40+ years later in 2005's "Guess Who". However, this adaptation has an obvious spin that shows just how far things have come by sticking with a situation of interracial relationships, but reversing the roles where a black family has to accept a white man as their daughter's choice in a spouse.Well made film for it's time.

reviews.review_title: Sorry, guys, it is a sell-out
reviews.content: It's interesting to read all these comments about the film. The reviews overall on this board have been pretty favourable for the movie. One user commented that the movie doesn't sell out. I beg to differ.The movie is pure, total sell-out. It's a watered down fanciful tale where "love will conquer everything." Generally speaking, I did not strongly dislike the film. There are some solid performances, particularly by the big three of Hepburn, Tracy and Poitier. At times it was funny. And one can not deny that it was fairly bold for its time. But taken in total, the film fails to truly deliver on what it promises.First and foremost, the movie is not about race. The film has about as much to do with race as The Cosby Show. Race is simply a stand-in for "differences." The filmmakers "sold out" when making this film when they decided to make Poitier an affluent world-class doctor and when they portrayed his fiancee's parents as San Francisco liberals. Any cultural or class differences between the races are whittled down to the point that there is little differentiating Poitier and his fiancee. What the movie ends up representing is the absolute best-case scenario for interracial relationships.Another detracting aspect of the film is the predictable characterizations of the parents. The father figures, the "reasonable" ones, seek to stop the marriage from going through because they feel that their children would have "special problems." The mothers, the "emotional" ones, want the marriage to go through because it's clear how happy and in love the couple is. In this manner the parents are pigeonholed into predictable gender-safe stereotypes with nary any complexity and without any true insight whatsoever into the notions of race and differences.All in all, Guess Who's Coming To Dinner disappoints because instead of an engaging discussion about race and the differing views on blacks coupling with whites, we are left with a "love can conquer all" message with little relevance to the issue at hand. Whereas other films since 1967 have engaged the true realities and complexities of interracial dating (most notably Spike Lee's far superior Jungle Fever), Poitier drifts through the screenplay aware that he is a "Negro," but seemingly only in name and appearance. The film is spoon-fed harmless morality which is all talk and little substance. The only character who is even aware of the differences between the races and chooses to challenge their relationship on those grounds is one of the more annoying characters, the fiancee's maid. She at least attempts to face up to what the real issue is instead of dancing around it during the whole movie. Her views are scripted to be watered-down, uneducated and condemnable, which in all fairness they are. But at least she raises the issue.I ended up rating this movie a six. It's decent entertainment, despite its one-dimensional characterizations (Hepburn aside) and lack of true social force. But it's definitely not anything I'd put in the top 100 films of all time.

reviews.review_title: Points for trying, but hokey even for 1967
reviews.content: Not a terrible film, and I give credit to all concerned for tackling the issues involved, but it falls flat mostly due to over-earnestness, and it's talk, talk, talkiness. Best aspect- watching the performances of Actor's actors Spencer Tracy and Beah Richards. Worst aspects- the hokey-ness (check out the spontaneous dancing exit of the maid and delivery boy), and the ridiculous performances by Katharine Houghton and Isabel Sanford. AND, the most puzzling thing I'm left with after watching this movie is- Why in the world would an amazing fellow like Sidney Poitier's character want to be with such an annoying little drip like that daughter in the first place?

This is a transitional movie. It rides the edge between realism and Harriet and Ozzie. I agree with earlier comments, the soundtrack is cheesy and several scenes are questionable at best. But, it is a great overall movie and worthy of watching many times. Favorite moments include Spencer Tracy saying "screw you" and watching Katherine Hepburn firing her gallery manager. But, the very best moment, and in my mind one of the most poignant pieces of film ever captured, is the look Spencer gives Katherine at the end of the film when he talks about his love for her. Clearly that is not about the characters, but really about Spencer and Katherine. "That look" is more than enough reason to watch this movie again and again.

reviews.review_title: Guess Who's Coming to Dinner - My Review
reviews.content: Well damn, if this wasn't the most awkward film I've ever seen. Not because it was bad, far from it. It was the situation. Most of the time I felt really disgusted at the white parents for their ignorance and hypocrisy, but at the same time I felt like I understood why they felt the way they do. They've grown up being more accepting than others, but were not exposed to the issue they supposedly supported.I didn't understand the black family's side too much, however. Maybe it's because I'm white, but even when they showed their perspective I was still feeling a little off about it. It dealt a lot with how blacks detested themselves and their skin color based on cultural and social opinion, which is still prevalent today and I completely understand why they feel that way (for instance: the father when being reprimanded by his son). However, I felt like we could have still gotten more out of the black family if they explained more as to why marrying a white person would be considered taboo. We all know why white families feel that way about blacks, but do blacks feel the same towards whites? Do they just hate them based on generational cruelty and hatred? Or a combination of the above? I feel so ignorant asking those questions, but I still struggle understanding since I am indeed a privileged white person and wish to treat everyone with respect. This movie did an amazing job with the messages it portrayed, as well as make me question myself and society in general. The sad part about it is that this film's message has not aged at all.

reviews.review_title: A good film and will be adding it to my collection.
reviews.content: "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner" is a drama/romance film that was released in1967. This film carried a strong cast, including Katharine Hepburn as Christina Drayton, Sidney Poitier as John Prentice, Katharine Houghton as Joey Drayton, and Spencer Tracy as Matt Drayton. This was the last film that Spencer Tracy made.
