I think that the movie is really good. it is a love story about two people who love each other, but they have to deal with their parents, first. It shows that we should all be equal---and think equal. And not to judge people by their color and appearance, instead look at them the way you look at your family/siblings...etc. and don't discriminate

reviews.review_title: A meaningful story in the most awkward way
reviews.content: I enjoyed this movie a lot because it really touched upon black and white acceptance in society and what was accepted and what was welcomed. I thought it was rather humorous that Joey's parents always taught her to be accepting towards black people however when she actually planned on marrying one her parents were shocked and a little uncomfortable with the idea. It showed that her parents were tolerable of black people living in the same society but it bothered them to welcome one into the family. John's parents also acted in a similar manner. When they met Joey at the airport they were shocked to see their son with a white woman. The mentality is not the same for both parents; Joey's parents were a little uncomfortable with the idea whereas John's parents were shocked because typically white people are less accepting of black people, at least during this time. I thought it was very good because it showed the level of acceptance on both sides and the trial and tribulations each parent overcame in accepting their child's choice in marrying the one they love no matter what their akin color is. The picture quality is very good and the lighting is good also because all the actors and actresses faces are bright and visible. I liked the awkwardness that was put into the acting and the camera work was coherent. Overall I thought this was an enjoyable movie and clearly portrayed the trials with race acceptance in society.

I like Sidney Poitier and I think he is a great actor but the direction he got for this movie was the worst. The plot is simple stilted and contrived. Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn act like they are has been's. This is like a one scene high school stage play. Very boring. This is not a classic time enduring play. It was out dated when it was produced. The most famous scene where Sidney Poitier faces off dad, Spencer Tracy, is so over acted, dramatized that and staged it looses reality. Actually the worst Act in a three act high school play. Dumb and dumber. I could go on and on but the movie isn't worth it and the Screen Actors' Guild should be ashamed of the movie.

reviews.review_title: Not Too Sure What the Idea of This Was
reviews.content: Although I am fully aware of what the plot of the movie was. I believe that there was way too much pushed into this movie that almost did not fit into the context. There were many powerful speeches in this movie, but I'm not really sure that they made sense into the movie. The idea of the plot was very good, especially in the time that the movie was released. What made it even better was that the African American man was not the type of man that most people thought he would be because of the color of his skin. I think the relationships between the two sets of parents took over the plot in itself. Overall, I am not really sure what the idea of all of the extra content in this movie was.

This is a refreshing movie about a couple fighting for their happiness in a world that doesn't accept them. You want them to be happy but they have to overcome adversity of their own families not accepting them. When they do overcome its cheesy but it feels right like you know its what you wanted for the characters but everything in the movie leads you to believe that they will never achieve the happiness you think they deserve. I imagine that this movie influenced many people on their views of interracial marriage when it came out. But their is nothing that makes this movie stand out as technically beautiful movie in the way that it was shot or lighted.

reviews.review_title: It has aged. But is still worth watching.
reviews.content:
When it was made it 1967, Guess Who's Coming to Dinner was relevant to the time, reflecting upon the changing times in America. African-Americans were protected by the law, but still were not respected by everyone, as Stanley Kramer showed in this movie about a debate between two families over an inter-racial marriage. While an overall good movie, some of its ideas have dated. First off, Sidney Poitier's character, in order to be worthy of the white girl (Katharine Houghton) has to be wealthy and a doctor who happens to work in Hawaii. Second, the subject of interracial marriage, while still not accepted by some, has become somewhat common in our society. The movie seems to stand better as a time capsule to the changing ideas of the late 60's.
The performances in the movie are good, though no actor stood out among the rest in my opinion. Katharine Hepburn did win an for her role as Houghton's mother. But, in my opinion, she didn't deserve it. She never gets to have a dramatic scene to herself. Through most of the movie she just stands and says words. The Oscar might also have been out of sympathy for long time lover Spencer Tracy's death, which occurred two weeks after the movie was completed. The film otherwise does have some good parts and I do recommend it. But it should be seen, as I said, as a reminder of how beliefs and ideals have changed since it was first released.

reviews.review_title: guess who's coming to dinner review
reviews.content: The film depicts interracial marriage in more of a positive light. During that time interracial marriage was still illegal in the southern states. Even though this was a good film it was still controversial. One scene in particular was when john was introduced the miss draydon. Her reaction to it gave you a sense of how many people during that time reacted. However the sad part with this is that up to this day their all still people in society that have a similar mindset. Even though it gives you an insight to that time period it shows similarities to today's day and age.

reviews.review_title: Movie Review: HIST of American Cinema 272
reviews.content:
"Guess Who's Coming to Dinner" is a fantastic movie directed by Stanley Kramer. This film tackles interracial marriage in the heat of the civil rights movement. Kramer draws you into the emotion of the characters almost immediately with the abrupt news of John and Joey to her parents that they are getting married after only knowing each other for ten days. The amazing acting of Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn and the expert direction of Kramer helped the audience share in the bewilderment of two parents that just found out their daughter is marrying someone she just met. Add into that the dilemma created by the racial situation in 1960s America and the film poses very interesting social questions.
There are many points of view from the lovers who want to get married, the mothers who accept that they are in love, fathers who understand its going to be hard and could cause trouble, and the social statements that the writers used to explain the complexities of the situation. One thing I thought was interesting was how they used the character of the maid, who was an older black lady, to convey how older black people felt about the civil rights movement. They were unsure, and worried about all the noise the young people were making. This is a great movie from the time when civil liberty was just beginning for people of color.

reviews.review_title: 10 days after, but love will never fail
reviews.content: For the time this movie came out, I think it really sheds light on the problem some may have with interracial marriage. This movie is a fantastic watch. Watching this movie in 2020 and knowing that there are people that still have an issue with interracial marriage concerns me quite a bit.Joanna Drayton falls in love with a sophisticated black man named John Prentice. John wants to marry her almost immediatly but feels as it they should have their parents blessing. They become engaged and then travel to San Francisco to meet Joanna's parents. Not by surprise in this time, the parents did not approve of her new love. Even after he said things such as, "There is nothing I wouldn't do for your daughter to keep her as happy as the day I met her." This movie really shows that anyone can love eachother and it shouldn't matter the skin color.I would recommend this this movie to anyone. The way this movie sheds light on the problems with interracial marriages is amazing and it shows that love is love, and no one should disapprove of that. The quotes in this film are absolutely fantastic.

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest black actors to ever live
reviews.content: This Movie is very touching to many people and it really proves how black peoples can take on a true role without it being about stereotypical insensitive roles. This movie does a great job with editing sounds, especially my favorite scene when John is speaking to his dad about how he doesn't own him, the sound is quiet but once John tells his dad he still lives him and how he sees himself as a man and not a colored man, the sound picks up and creates a stronger emotion inside the viewer as you easily understand how John is feeling. The scene is very powerful and it has a couple camera cuts going back and forth from John and to his dad. The actors do a great job, especially the mother Christina when she first meets john, you can see the look of disbelief and shock in her. The movie includes a series of close ups, tracking shots, over the shoulder and others. The movie is easily one of my favorites due to the fact that the directors knew what to add to make each scene feel important whether it be from camera angle or audio. Overall I enjoyed this film

Although I really applaud the purpose of this movie and the awareness that it was trying to arouse, I felt like it was still not very practical. There were situations in the movie that were unrealistic and made the issue of interracial marriage easier to deal with then in real life. For example, the chances of finding any man, whether he be white, black, yellow, orange, or purple with the credentials as John Prentice is extremely slim. If John Prentice had an occupation that was more realistic like a banker or a doctor, then it would have made the situation a lot harder. Also, the opening scene where the happy couple was merrily waltzing through the airport I found to be enormously naïve and completely not representative of the context of the time period. Also the priest in the movie was very accepting and supportive of the couple's marriage and was wondrously happy for them, but that was not an accurate representation of all the churches and their views on interracial marriage. I know of churches and institutions today that frown upon interracial marriage and they believe that interracial marriage is not willed by God, and if churches like that exist today I can know they were more extreme in the 1960s. However, despite these historical inaccuracies in the movie its purpose is clearly there. It served to increase awareness of race and ethnicity and to challenge people to act out what they say about equality and about the color of someone's skin not making a difference.

This movie was just completely outstanding. I understand it was very controversial for the time but I truly loved it. The acting is just outstanding and the story is beautiful. The scripting was truly magnificent as well.

reviews.review_title: Dealing with race is never easy
reviews.content: Race is not an easy concept to deal with a movie, and in this comedy-drama hybrid race is the dinner table conversation. This film does an excellent job of describing the issues that arise when we see interracial marriage in 60's-70's. In some ways the film has lost a little of its message, just because its not as important as it once was. But some of the other issues it deals with are still very relevant. The issue of hypocrisy, and how we deal with issues that we talk about all the time and yet have never faced. Its also about dealing with the generation gap, a major theme of the time which has in some ways slipped away now. Poitier does an excellent job throughout this movie, and the interactions between he and Houghton are hilarious throughout. A great movie, even if some of its message is lost to a more liberal age.

This movie is fantastic. From the dreamy setting, to the characters wardrobe, and finally to the unlikely love story, this movie hit it out of the park. While the film was heavy with its plot of race and love, it was lightened with its charming and bubbly characters, who clearly knew what they wanted in life. Overall, this movie was extremely well written and heartfelt.

reviews.review_title: A great Movie as well as Important
reviews.content: This movie was really good; the acting was good, costumes, and the lighting. The costumes fit the time period and were sometimes extravagant, the lighting was a bit darker throughout the film and gave a neutral feeling; it wasn't a good feeling, but it wasn't a bad feeling either. The acting was really good with the first shock of the parents and how they get used to the that was well done. Sidney Poitier was fantastic in this film; I feel like he put in a lot of feeling into his role as Dr. John Prentice. I like how Kate Hepburn preformed her crying scenes because it was really convincing that she was feeling happy or sad with those tears. I give this movie an 8 out of 10 because I feel like it's an important film and it touches on a subject that was frowned upon at that time and it was very well done.

reviews.review_title: Week 13 IMBd: Guess Who's Coming to Dinner
reviews.content: At the beginning of this film we are introduced to the biracial couple of John Prentice (Sidney Poitier) and Christina Dayton (Katherine Hepburn). They get their luggage and get in a taxi to go meet up with Christina's parents As they get to the house John is immodestly ridiculed by Tillie (Isabel Sanford) for being with Christina the wrong reasons. Soon after Joey(Katherine Houghton) and Matt Drayton (Spencer Tracy) meet John. Both are taken a back by the suddenness of the advancements of the relationship and other things. As they retreated to gather their thoughts, Christina invites Johns parents to her house and dinner later at night. Mr Prentice and Mrs. Prentice eventually show up to the Drayton household and immediately sensed the situation was different. Monsignor Ryan a friend of the draytons was also at the dinner. While the Prentices were getting comfortable, Ryan tries to ease Matts fears of the relationship. Before the dinner starts many of the the persons at the party had several one on ones conversation.Near the end of the night Matt calls everyone together to make announcement. He let the crew know that John and Christina couldn't be held apart regardless of the ridicule they were going to face being a biracial couple. Diner begins.Guess who's coming to dinner is a very polarizing film. It directly attacks a tender issue of inter racial marriage. Instead of having the parents taking a racist point of view they had just feared the way society would treat the couple. Which is a shot at the American Society. The way the built the minor characters in a way of how society would react to them is an amazing detail during the film. The movie is needed for the time. It is a great catalyst for change. Through the way the main character and side characters interact it shows the sickness in society.

Having watched a few clips in class, I thought Guess Who's Coming to Dinner (1967) might prove hard to make it through, but I was surprised to find out otherwise (and also happy).Guess Who's Coming to Dinner (1967) clearly had a political and social agenda as well as being entertaining. Guess Who's Coming to Dinner ('67) shows racism (intended and unintended) from a few different angles: from an upper class white family judging their white daughter's black fiancé; from a middle class black family judging their son's white fiancé; and from the white family's black maid accusing the black fiancé, Dr. Prentice, of getting "above" himself. I thought the film was well rounded in providing several different views on the "problem" (a white woman marrying a black man), and at supplying a remedy that advocated civil rights and equality.

reviews.review_title: a last look at a beautiful romance
reviews.content: I love and hate this movie. Not because of the plot, or the story, or the issue it deals with. i love it for 2 reasons: Kate and Spencer. They were together for 27 years in real life, defying all odds in an unlikely romance. Spencer's last lines on screen melt me to tears every time. it is only fitting that one of the best actors of all time would spend his last moments on screen with the love of his life, someone who just happened to be the best and most important actress of all time. what i hate is that this beautiful love story was almost over. 10 days after completing the movie, Spencer died in his love's arms. here ends the most fabulous romance of all time. (SPOILER ALERT) Remember Spencer's last words on screen to Kate; "all that matters is what they feel, and if it is 1/2 of what we felt, that's everything." he was looking straight at Kate(who was not on camera, the shots of her and him were spliced together), he was telling the world of their love, he was paying tribute to before millions. he was saying goodbye. if you havent seen this movie, do so for them. o-by the way-i love it, and i am only 15.

reviews.review_title: A Warm and Optimistic Film That Tackles the Subject Matter In a Sensitive and Modern Way
reviews.content: Travelling back to 1967 we find a film that tackles the issue of race and interracial marriage at a time when attitudes were starting to change, but perhaps not fast enough. This is still a prevalent theme in films, most recently explored in 'Get Out' directed by Jordan Peele, which starts pretty much in the same way as 'Guess Who's Coming to Dinner?', but which takes a much darker turn. However, the best genre for exploring these issues is comedy-drama, which is what 'Guess Who's Coming to Dinner?' is, as this enables the arguments and discussions had by the various characters to be shown and to evolve, as well as to lay their prejudices and beliefs open for us to laugh at, but also in many ways recognise. The simple beauty of this film is that it is allowed to be, there isn't any external pressure on it to throw in plot twists and excitement; it is simply a two-hour discussion on the topic of racism and interracial marriage. However, it has such engaging and genuine characters that it is an enjoyable discussion, and never really gets dull. The plot is also really simple, which as I have stated, works as strength, rather than a weakness. 23-year-old Joanna 'Joey' Drayton, returns home to San Francisco, after a holiday in Hawaii, to introduce her parents to her fiancé, 37-year-old academic Dr John Prentice, whom she met while she was there, only 10 days earlier. There is only one problem: he is black and she is white. The simplest of set-ups makes for a wonderful character study, and for exploring the issues of acceptance being pushed to its limit. Because nobody in this film is an actual racist. Joey's parents, Christina and Matt (played brilliantly by Katherine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy), are nice, middle-class, liberal people who brought their daughter up to believe that the colour of a person's skin should not make a difference as to how you treat them, and Joey is certain that her parents will not raise any objections to her choice of husband. John, however, is a little more sceptical, knowing how racism is much more deeply embedded than just what a person believes politically. Therefore, John decides that he will only marry Joey if her parents give their blessings whole-heartedly, and without any reservations, but they have only until that evening to decide as he is flying out to New York that night, and then on to Geneva to lecture at the World Health Organisation, where Joey will join him and they will be married. This plot device is a little weak, as it creates a false sense of tension about whether the parents will bless the marriage or not, and it steers the debate in a definite direction, rather than letting it flow naturally. Despite this the issues are tackled incredibly well for a '60s film, with a real sense of hypocrisy shown to be the main problem rather than just open racism. As I said, Joey's parents are all for black equality until their daughter confronts them with her black fiancé, which takes them aback a little, especially Mr Drayton. They have a black maid called Tilly, who brought Joey up, which harkens back to the days of slavery, especially as even the assistant housekeeper, Dorothy, is a young black woman. However the message of the film does appear to be that racism is only something that the older generation experience, as the young people in the film don't seem to be aware there is a problem: Joey can't think that her parents could take issue with her marriage, her fashionable friends, Peter and Judith, are only pleased for her, and don't even mention the colour of John's skin, and the aforementioned Dorothy's (implied) boyfriend is a white delivery boy. Indeed, this gives a strange sense of optimism to the film, that when the older generation are dead and buried, issues regarding race will be a thing of the past. The only people who believe there is a problem are the older people: Joey's parents, the maid Tilly, who thinks Dr Prentice is getting above himself, Mrs Drayton's colleague at the Art Gallery she runs who is appalled at the idea of intermarriage, and John's parents who are typical working-class black people, and think the whole idea is ridiculous. The only older person who breaks this mould is the Irish Catholic priest, Mike, who heavily supports the idea of them being married; because he believes having to fight the prejudice that will follow them will bring them closer together. In fact, the only real obstacle are the fathers of the couple, especially Joey's father, who doesn't object on racist grounds, but on the grounds that he doesn't want his daughter to have all the trouble that such a marriage could cause. As I have said, the characters are also a real strength of this film as they are 3- dimensional and not caricatures, a trap this movie could easily have fallen into. Joey is optimistic and naïve, yes, but at the same time she genuinely loves John, and there is almost a sense that she knows there is a problem, but is trying to ignore it. Dr John Prentice, played excellently by Hollywood's then token black star Sidney Poitier, is noble and dignified, and intelligent, who knows more about the race issue than his bride-to-be, but is also funny and playful. He can also be pushed to his limit, making him very human and not just a 2-D cut-out for the debate to be focused on, and the relationship between him and Joey feels very loving and real. Joey's parents are also loving, both to each other and their daughter, which makes the drama when something comes between them genuinely compelling. Hepburn plays the mother as a woman who struggles with this issue herself, but is determined to accept it to make Joey happy, but who must also fight with her husband, who isn't as accepting as her; Tracy also does a sterling job as the father who just wants what's best for his daughter, and believes she has made a massive error of judgement. The way he makes throwaway racist comments, without meaning any harm, is also very clever and reveals a lot about how racism isn't based on hate but on ignorance. It is also a comedy and so it does have some very funny moments and dialogue, which makes us stop and look at ourselves and our own attitudes towards race. It is a very warm, optimistic film, perhaps a little naïve at times, but cleverly makes the whole situation about love not hatred, and has an incredibly modern feel to it. Of course it does have its flaws, the '60s vibe and references do feel a little dated and laughable now, which is to be expected, but personally I feel they do add a charm to the film, which makes it enjoyable to watch, even if it does occasionally make you cringe. Also as I have said before, the plot device of the marriage only being able to go ahead if Joey's parents agree is a little misguided as it then makes the film more about trying to persuade Mr Drayton to bless the marriage before the day is over, than about the characters' reactions to this news, and it makes the second half of the film drag a little. The last scene is also a little slow, despite the fact it is supposed to be the climax of the entire debate, as Joey invites John's parents to dinner over the phone, when he hasn't told them his fiancée is white, and they all have to sit down together, but it just seems to drag as they all just re-discuss and recycle everything they've already said, and the ending does feel a little anti-climactic. Also there is a strange backstory that John had been married before but lost his wife and son in an accident, which has no bearing on the story and is never really raised again. The word 'negro' is also bandied about a bit too much for a modern audience to be comfortable with, and the 'n' word is said once, only by the black maid, but considering a white person wrote the script, it's enough to make you shudder. Apart from this though, it is a very well-written film that feels startlingly modern in the way it handles the 'race-issue', whose message is of course that black people should be treated as people, not black people, which is shown through the representation of John and Joey's parents being almost parallel versions of each other, suggesting that we are all the same underneath the skin. It avoids being stereotypical in the way it deals with the issues raised, and the characters avoid being 'types' or caricatures, and above all it is a brilliant family drama that also explores the relationships within families, and how nobody behaves perfectly when pushed to their limits. Overall, a film that still remains relevant today and handles the debate it sets up sensitively and with an optimistic outlook that things will improve, as long as the younger generation from both races continue to break down the barriers previous generations have set up.

I have only recently seen this movie for the first time, although the title is known to me.Sidney Poitier's character is PERFECT.  And not because he needed to be perfect so the white audience would accept him.  He's everything Spencer Tracy would want in a son-in-law.  He's successful, well-known, and respected in his field.  He has only one problem -- he's black.  If he was just an "ordinary" black guy (or ordinary white guy for that matter), then the tough decision Tracy needs to make would be moot.  Because the ONLY thing he can object to is Poitier's race, the movie works.I'm surprised that the Oscar was not given to Tracy posthumously. Katherine Hepburn's performance was just OK, but Tracy stole the picture.  Even Poitier was "as expected"--low key, intense, and likable.Tracy's speech at the end of the picture nearly brought tears to my eyes. It was both moving and humorous, and delivered with honesty and passion.I give this movie 9 out of 10 stars.

I really didn't know what to expect when the movie started. But after realizing the time period that the movie was in and the people that were involved I knew that it was going to be a stick situation. Although the movie it self was odd to me I thought the acting was actually really good. Joey Drayton was my favorite not only because she was pretty attractive but she played the role really well, falling in a love with a guy and hoping her father approves. John Prentice was also very good and he respected her. Their mothers to me were basically the same person. The father of the girl was a typical father of a girl being skeptical of a daughters decision but especially because he was African American. Overall the movie was OK and not at all what i expected. I probably wouldn't watch it again but thats just me.

Guess Who's Coming to Dinner deals with affluent, socially liberal parents struggling with the news that their young daughter wants to marry a successful black man. The wardrobes, scenery and sets are elegant and beautiful making the movie very easy to watch. The realistic portrayal of the parents struggle with whether or not to give their consent and approval, with the story being told over the course of one day, is compelling. We all struggle with developing our personal value system, and this movie exhibits how it can be difficult when life puts you to the test. This film was not only entertaining, but it makes you think about the content and the message well afterwards.

reviews.review_title: Groundbreaking at the time, but hasn't aged well
reviews.content: This is one of those classic movies you almost feel you "have" to love--it has a stellar cast, a (for the time) edgy, pushing-the-envelope feel, and of course, the enormous emotional impact of seeing the final Hepburn-Tracy film (Spencer Tracy looks so weak and *old* in this film, it's heartbreaking).Any yet . . . while it may have really caused hairs to stand on end in 1967, it doesn't play as well today. First of all, it's so incredibly TALKY. I've seen very few films, even those faithfully adapted from stage plays, where the actors spend so much of their time standing or sitting around, drinks in hand, engaging in faux-Socratic dialog on this or that. And to think this was written directly for the screen by the same man who wrote the manic "It's a Mad Mad Mad Mad World" and the slapstick-y "The Russians Are Coming! The Russians Are Coming!" A second problem is the performances. I was a huge fan of Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy, and feel that Sidney Poitier is one of the greatest living actors. Yet in this film, we see none of the verbal sparks that Hepburn and Tracy generated in other films (notably "Pat and Mike") and precious little of the fire that Poitier is capable of. To be fair, Tracy's illnesses (diabetes, among others) almost certainly reined in his performance. But the other actors didn't have that excuse.Unfortunately, films that deal with contemporary social issues often don't last. "In the Heat of the Night", for example, while very fine as a murder mystery, seems overblown in treating racism, and the southern characters (except for Rod Steiger's wonderfully complex police chief) are paper-cutout caricatures. That same sad fate has befallen "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner".

This movie is great if you want a romantic comedy, but if you're looking for a movie that truly represents who people felt about interracial marriages in the 1960s, this isn't it. In this movie, the characters for the most part are too accepting and love matters most. When Joey brought home John, her black fiancé, her mother was shocked, but then accepted it because of Joey's happiness. Joey's father, Matt, would not give his approval because of the ridicule the couple would face and the struggle they would go through. John's parents had similar reactions. In the end, the parents gave their children their blessings. This seems very unrealistic. Times were changing, but there weren't there yet. Some people still have a hard time accepting interracial couples now. There is great dialog in this movie and Heptburn and Tacy are wonderful.

reviews.review_title: Guess Who's Coming to Dinner (1967) - a classic film that helps to shape opinions
reviews.content: While I feel this movie is a classic, my personal opinion is that the daring plot and storyline create its classic reputation. In my opinion, (the opinion of a 20-year-old college student who considers himself a casual film enjoyer, so take my opinion with a HEAVY grain of salt), films such as "Imitation of Life" (1934) do a better job of depicting and changing the conversation around race-relations in The United States. "Imitation of Life" (1934) is over 30 years older than "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner" (1967), and, (once again) in my opinion, does a better job of convincing the audience of the desired outcome.Many films that seek to push a viewpoint, no matter how moral, apolitical, humane, or anything else of that nature, tend to be very 'in your face'. For instance, think of not agreeing with a late-night comedian. The laugh track is directed at YOU and all fo the jokes become about how ignorant you must be. In the case of "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner" (1967), the film does a great job of developing characters in a way that you feel for them and respect their viewpoints. Allowing you to see yourself in the characters and feel respected, no matter which opinion you may have on the interracial couple.

This movie, despite appearing fluffy and "light" dealt with important societal issues of the 1960s and 1970s. Though most of the actors in the film were very successful and well-known (among these actors were Hepburn and Poitier) I didn't feel the characters the represented, nor the film as a whole, commanded/demanded that these actors use all of their talent. Despite dealing with important issues of interracial marriage, I felt the overall movie was unrealistic. Everyone in the movie was wealthy, including the Prentice family (despite Mr. Prentice being a retired postal worker); furthermore, it seems preposterous that Joey's family would care solely for their daughter's happiness. I enjoyed the movie, thought it was light and fun, but felt that overall, the movie was unrealistic.

I have nothing but good things to say about this film although it was probably not an accurate representation of life during this time it portrayed something that should be accepted by all. This film was filled with love from every member of John and Joey's family. Although there were members of their families that may not have been too supportive but it was never due to racism, it was due to the fear of what John and Joey would go through because of racist individuals they may come across. The parents were my favorite parts of the film. The love that the parents had for their child showed immensely throughout the film, there was no judgement of their child's choices. There was actually the opposite, the parents had respect for their choices and were proud of the individuals they raised. Although there were negative people in the film such as Tillie and Hilary, they represented two different ends of the spectrum. Tillie, a black woman, represented the reaction of a black person who may not feel as though an interracial marriage could happen and was judgmental of the idea of a black man marrying into a wealthy white family and getting the same respect that she would give the white people she worked for. Where as Hilary represented the racism that was occurring at that time. Hilary never accepted the possibility that the interracial couple could be accepted, her only explanation for what was going on was that something was wrong with Joey and that she was in danger. Joey's mother not only shot down the idea that there was something wrong with her daughter but also removed Hilary from the families life which also removed the racism from the film. Although this may not be an accurate representation of what many happen in this time I found it to be refreshing to have a black man portrayed as a doctor rather than someone who cleans for a white person and to have white people look at a black man as an equal and eventually as part of their family.

First of all there is no doubt that the performances are great! Sidney Poitier is totally convincing with hes struggle to seek his parents approval. The problem lies in the slow pace. It seems as though every other scene is of private conversations lading to the ultimate speech. The speech was good but expected. And even that takes too long. All i could think about was, when the hell are these people going to sit down and eat dinner? Never. The film makers intended to make a drama but I think that this film would have been much more successful as a comedy, even when it came out in 67. This film touches on very important topics in a very serious way. Too serious. The lack of comedic relief pushed me to the point of resting my head on my hands so I wouldn't fall asleep.

I thought that this movie was important that it addressed interracial issues at a time when they were of great discussion, but I thought that everything seemed too perfect. John Prentice is a doctor known around the world and has had great success in all of his occupational endeavors. Also, he has faced a great tragedy in his life being the loss of his child and wife. I do not how the Draytons could not accept him whether he was of any color. He has faced great success and unfortunate circumstances in his life, and therefore he would be very able to care for and guide Joey in her young life. I feel that to give the film a better sense of reality, writers should have given Prentice a mix of humanistic qualities and flaws that may better represent the nature of human characteristics.

This film, is one of the first films to positively portray the topic of an interracial coupling. Prior to this film, it was very rare that am interracial relationship would be portrayed, let alone portrayed in a positive way. I liked the way that this film showed that women, mothers, have more passion when it comes to matters of the heart, then men, father's do. It is in my opinion, and experience, that this is true, and it was nice to see this portrayed in a film. Another interesting aspect of this film was that one of the stars, Spencer Tracy, passed away right before this film was completed, and that some of the other characters in the film never watched the completed version due to the painful memories that it was related to.

Guess Who's Coming to Dinner was a great movie that was very controversial due to the time period that it was released. This movie exploring and walked the line of interracial couples. This was the first film to show this type of relationship and it brought up much controversy. This black man was a successful doctor which also isn't found very often in this time period. Joey Drayton brings her fiancé, Doctor John Prentice, to meet her parent's who are very liberal. They were not a big fan of the relationship. John's family ended up coming to dinner and the two father's at first agreed that the couple should not marry, the mother's did not agree with them. This movie carried a tremendous amount of dialog but it was enjoyable and necessary dialog.

reviews.review_title: Awkward conversation makes its way to film
reviews.content: Guess Who's Coming to Dinner is a movie with much thought. The film's has a lot to say and it does. All actors in the film show their distrust with one another perfectly, and the transitional shots are phenomenal. Funny The Who is brought up, yet is on the verge of collapse nowadays.

Stanley Cramer's "Guess Whos Coming to Dinner" is a film that was ahead of its time for its 1967 release. This films most prominent theme confronts the racial tensions in the United States during the 1960's, a theme that is still relevant in 2020. Cramer shines a light on prejudice by focusing on how discriminatory attitudes and views effect even the most isolated situations, such as the potential marriage of an inter racial couple. Sidney Portlier and Katherine Houghton play a young couple (Dr. John Prentice & Joey Drayton) who unexpectedly visit Joey's parents, with news that the two plan to be married. But once Joey's parents find out John is black and Johns parents that Joey is white, chaos consumes the household. The film explores the dynamics between the couple and their families as their fathers object to the marriage. It is specifically interesting that the film chose to portray Mr. Drayton as a liberal who has publicly fought against injustice and racism in his local newspaper, yet doesn't feel comfortable with his own daughter marrying outside of her race. "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner" does seamless job of exploring the United States varying points of view and stereotypes of the time on a smaller scale. Although there are serious messages of hypocrisy and prejudice, as well as true love, there is a mixture of genuine comedy throughout. I enjoyed all the performances, especially Sidney Poitier as Dr. Prentice and Katherine Hepburn as Mrs. Drayton. I would recommend this film to everyone, there is a message that found within that is a significant now as it was in 1967.

This drama, and somewhat comedy, directly revolves around one political topic; race. This means of course that it will be very touchy to talk about. However, this film is a perfect representation on how society should grow warm to change. This movie teaches about how love matters in a non-physical sense, what the eyes cannot see.I think that this film contains great qualities. First of all, a fantastic plot, somewhat similar to "Romeo and Juliet" in the sense of two lovers not supposed to be together. The story is interesting and revolves around one setting, the home of the girl's family. This is good because it means there was not much moving around or action, which is good for character development because they are not dying, it also means more dialogue. This allows the audience to see how the characters were all somewhat dynamic and complex. Every character changes throughout the film, some more than others. I liked this because it allows the audience to acquire a sense of compassion for each character, and allows them to see the point of view of another side. This may now affect that person in the audience to look at their neighbors differently and be less ignorant.The acting was also phenomenal and I think that this movie is so powerful because it was current affair. It was a real thing that couples had to get past and through the power of film, you can create sympathy and I think this movie did a great job at doing that.

reviews.review_title: The Film That Will Never Age
reviews.content: I saw Guess Who's Coming to Dinner about three months ago, yet the experience still stays with me and will last me for a lifetime.  The addressing of the time-weathered issue of interracial dating by itself is reason enough to go and see it, but the directing, the Oscar-winning screenplay, and the spectacular acting of the cast (highlighted by Katherine Hepburn's Oscar-winning performance) makes this movie a classic.  I urge everyone who thinks that they are totally unbiased and free from racial prejudice and stereotyping should watch this movie at least four times, putting themselves in the position of each of the parents.  Bravo, Mr. Kramer!  You made me a believer in the true art of social awareness in the film industry.

reviews.review_title: Tillie and John as representatives of the times
reviews.content: Although the setting of the film is unusual (one would have never seen a black man with a white woman) for the time, it is an excellent example of interesting issues that carry over to today's world of racial awareness. One of the most interesting aspects of the film is the maintenance of stereotypical characters while at the same time making advances for the portrayal of African American people in films. This is especially present in the characters of Tillie and John. John represents the new type of character that achieves almost entire equality, while Tillie represents the old "Mammy" character that is caring, affectionate, strong, and wise.From the interactions between these two characters it is clear that Tillie represents the old point of view that interracial couples are bad and John and Joanna represent the new emerging wave of people that feel differently about interracial couples than those who raised them. At the end of the film Mrs. Prentice appeals to Matt Drayton and talks some sense into him. She shows him that race is not as big of a deal as they had all thought and that both John and Joanna's parents have been wrong. This shows the advancement of African Americans from servile roles to roles in which they are not belittled by their white co-stars.

I thought this movie was wonderful. Everything from the acting to the editing was done well. It focuses on the issues on that time, racial marriage. Though, now a days, no one would be iffy about their daughter marrying a Yale graduate and a doctor, but back then it was different. His career path and what he was involved in definitely did help him in ways, but for both sides of the family, they were more concerned with the fact that one was white and one was black. This was a common shared feeling back then. This is both a romantic film about love, but it is also a comedy I feel. There are funny parts in it, even though the subject matter is serious. I enjoyed this movie a great deal and I would recommend seeing it!

This movie is a very interesting portrayal of interracial marriage. I find it to be an entertaining story of "love conquering all," but it does not tackle any of the weighty issues that should have been discussed. The movie presents all characters as the "best" of society, and all problems as having a simple solution. The fact of the matter is, the real world would have been much different for this couple than what is portrayed on screen. The audience is never given a chance to see all the problems that are discussed for 2 hours in the movie. Kramer was forced to play to his audience of mainly white theater-goers, and had to sugar-coat his portrayal of interracial marriage. Although the movie was revolutionary for it's time, it is not the reality of it's time.

This used to be one of my favorite movies, but oh my heavens. It's got some very cute parts, but other parts that are just so cringeworthy now! Especially the maid character Tilly, as played by Isabelle Sanford. Oof. Interestingly, the problems that were worth talking about in 1967 are for the most part still problems in 2022. I was in elementary school in his first came out, and I remember the uproar that it caused, it was considered so crazy liberal. Now it seems almost conservative, where the parents are asked to approve the marriage. I love all the actors, they're all brilliant, so just watching the acting can be satisfying.

reviews.review_title: Great movie that explores civil rights and true love simultaneously.
reviews.content: A list of stars are featured in 1967's Guess Who's Coming to Dinner, a story of a black man and a white woman who fall in love and then have to deal with the hard part: convincing both sets of parents to approve of their relationship. This is a really good movie on a couple of levels. First, for the time frame (and forgive me, I wasn't actually alive when this came out), it is a nice "transition film" that subtley speaks out against the ridiculous attitudes of many upper middle class families concerning their biogtous ways. No matter what positions they claim to have taken (and Tracy's character is embroiled in his own claim to be a champion of the civil rights movement), their real attitudes are only expressed "when it happens to them" (e.g. your daughter wants to get married to a black man...how do you feel about this?). Secondly, the acting is great. It evicts emotions. You see the the men because they are interrupting true love and you cheer for the women, because they crusade to put their offspring first. Even the married couple is expressed differently. Joey is a naive soul who believes her parents are the best thing since sliced bread. John is a fighter. He's the most sincere fellow you'd meet, but he knows what he wants and he's not afraid to speak his mind to anyone (while at the same time not wanting to step on Drayton's toes about the situation). The ending is classic: It doesn't "sell out" to the plot and it makes me admire the days when Spencer Tracy was king and regret that this film was his last.

45 years after its release, GWCTD is still a cinematic delight. This movie is not my generation and I could not identify that it had some of the most well-known actors of its time like Spencer Tracy, Katherine Hepburn. Though it was dealing with a sensitive topic of its times, it was handled very delicately by both the script-writer and the director.But the handling of the issue was not the high point of the movie for me. What amazed me after watching this movie was the honesty with which it was written. Ignoring 1-2 digressions, the plot stuck to what it had to convey. The sequencing and the flow of scenes made sense, and I must add that it is not easy to do this in such low-decibel drama movies. It was an emotional ride for all the character's involved, except maybe Joey who for her age had to be shown as a young immature young woman who could not see beyond her love. The dialogue were straight to the point - I don't remember a single dialogue which was out of line or not relevant. It was a good clean script. Near-absence of background music added to the drama and am guessing it created an environment that Mr.Stanley Kramer intended. Well, he succeeded.I could recognize only Mr.Sidney Poitier and he delivered a powerful & straightforward character performance. While reading some other reviews I realized that this was Mr.Spencer Tracy's last movie and that too with Katharine Hepburn with whom he had an off-screen love affair. The veterans pulled this one off with amazing simplicity. The last scene where Mr.Tracy delivers his speech was a fitting culmination to the emotional drama that unfolded in the previous 90-95 minutes.To summarize, GWCTD is a good clean Sunday afternoon cinema which I would recommend to anyone. 8 out of 10 for me.

At first I was nervous watching this because of the racial differences but it wasn't to bad . Although these couple fell in love to quick I love the way they fight to be together . I already knew the parents were going to give them a hard time. But not going out without a fight and what they believed in and not judging by the color of there skin was amazing . Great movie

reviews.review_title: review for Guess Who's Coming To Dinner
reviews.content: This was a very good movie, in my opinion. I thought that for it's time period it hit a lot of issues that are still very current, which makes the movie almost feel like it was made recently. I thought the actors had very good chemistry also. I liked the use of the lighting as well. It wasn't straight forward high key/low key. Some dramatic scenes were done inside with bright light and vise versa for some less dramatic scenes. I thought the fathers speech at the end was the perfect touch. I feel like he said everything just right and really let the audience know how he truly felt. The true emotions in this movie I believe made it the movie it is. I think if the actors didn't do such a good job at connecting with one another, the movie wouldn't of came out as good as it did.

Sidney Poitier gives a wonderful performance as he deals with his new fiance's family. The film as a whole deals with the issue of interracial marriage at a time when marrying someone that had a different skin color was a controversial act. The message the film conveys is important, which is that love, regardless of who it is the love is for, is more important than any issues that may be due to someone's race.

I was a teen when I saw that film and loved it. The actors were great , the scenario ( San Francisco ) was beautiful. The story was interesting and told in a light way. The Spencer Tracy's final speech made me cry ...as Hepburn did ...what a sincere interpretation!!!! Some years ago I bought the film in VHS and after in DVD and I can't tell how many times I saw that film. But I can say that since 1998 , every time I listened the song "The Glory of Love" ( played in the film by Frank de Vol and Orchestra) I remembered the film, San Francisco ( a city that I love ) and the final speech. "You've got to give a little, loose a little and let your poor heart break a little, thats the glory of , thats the story of love ..."

Guess Who is Coming to Dinner is an OK film. It was directed by Stanley Kramer and was released in 1967. The film presents a sort of controversial plot. The daughter Joey Drayton played by Katherine Houghton has fallen in love with a smart wealthy black man named John Prentice played by Sydney Poitier. When Joey brings John home to introduce him to his parents they are shocked because at the time interracial marriage was not common. From there the film basically takes us through the drama of the situation, and is not very eventful at all. The acting is very good and the cinematography is done very well, in this sense it is a good film, however the plot is kind of boring.

In any Spencer Tracy & Katharine Hepburn movie, you could always tell their love for each other no matter what movie they were in. Guess Who's Coming To Dinner was their last film together. Shortly after completing the filming of the movie, Spencer Tracy passed away from a heart attack. That movie was a movie telling the true meaning of love no matter what race or colour you were. The catchy tune, The Glory of Love, sung by Bette Midler, was perfect for this movie. In life, it's not all lah-dee-dah, you've gotta cry a little, laugh a little, win a little, loose a little, you can't always win even if your Albert Einstein, and that's the story of life.

This movie, led by the brilliant Sidney Poitier, pushes the limits of what was socially allowed at the time. When main character Joanna shows up at her home with a surprise, little do her normally liberal parents know that the surprise is a black fiancé, something that was still so taboo back in the 60's. Joanna's parents, played by Spencer Tracy and Katherine Hepburn, carry this movie. They are amazing in working with each-other back and forth with dialogue and physical motions. There is a chemistry between the two that is impossible to ignore. The film brings in Poitier's parents to join the dinner. The film takes place over one day and pushes the boundaries of what was acceptable. Almost 50 years later, I am so glad that it did.

Ohhh boy, I cannot imagine the headlines and controversy this movie may have created in the late 60's! As I sit home and home school my daughters about Fiction and non-Fiction. I can't help but wonder about the reality this topic brought into people's homes. Fantastic acting all around in this movie it totally overshadowed the limited settings. As a father of two Caucasian girls, I have to think what if? But it is 2020, should I even be thinking what if? Really good movie check it out.

reviews.review_title: Guess Who's Coming to Dinner - Analysis
reviews.content: Throughout the movie, camera distance consisted of medium close-up shots, medium shots, and medium-long shots that display multiple people in conversation and their expressions. Also, most of the scenes consisted of hard low-key lighting, which emphasis the severe tone of the movie and shows all the wrinkles and blemishes of the characters. An example of this is at the end of the film, when Matt Drayton is accepting John and Joey's love. An old a serious-looking Matt was explaining his approval of the interracial marriage.At the beginning and end of the movie, there was non-diegetic intro and outro music that took over the sound of the film completely. An example of this is at the beginning when John and Joey are talking and leaving the airport; you can't hear any dialog or background noise of the airport.

The feeling I got out of this movie was that love will conquer all. It was quite obvious that in the big speech Tracy was speaking his heart to Kate Hepburn. The message of the movie is, if you love someone strong enough you can overcome all problems, that message will never be dated. The film is also surprisingly funny, the moments when the parents figure out whats happening and the nervousness Poitier feels about telling mom and dad about his white girlfriend are well worth renting the movie on there own. The number one reason to watch the movie is to just see the greatest screen couple of all time, one last time. Like an earlier comment noted the tears in Miss Hepburns eyes are real.

Imagine a drama that focused on a controversial topic. Now imagine it's over forty years old and the controversial topic is not even remotely an issue.Guess who's coming to dinner is about inter-racial marriage and how it was weird for old people. The soundtrack is nothing of interest, the drama only stems from the inter-racial aspect, and the dialog comes off a bit preachy (especially at the end). It just doesn't work when it's so common, in fact it's almost comical how out of date it is.Some of the scenes are also painfully dated. Between the delivery boy and the malt shop, it's hardly relate-able. Who thought dialog about boysenberry ice cream was a good idea in the first place?On the other hand, it does have Spencer Tracy, and it provided a strong message towards inter-racial marriage. Perhaps I'm a tad cynical, but watching it in the modern age, it's simply too dated to have any affect.

reviews.review_title: People like it because it "has deep social messages"
reviews.content:
This review has no spoilers, because within the first ten minutes you will be able to recite the entire plot by heart. I won't tell you how anything ends, but you'll know by reading the description anyway... let's jump in.
This movie is trite, boring and repetitive. The parents in this film are opposed to their daughter's marriage to a guy they literally met hours ago? Subconscious racists I guess. If I become a parent, I am not giving my kids my support if the decide to marry someone I've never met before. I don't care if it has great messages about liberalism (it doesn't and I'll explain later), give me characters who make sense. The owners of a liberal newspaper aren't going to be horrified if their daughter wants to marry a black man, they wouldn't care. The couple are brats, they overreact to their parents not wanting to endorse their marriage to a person they don't know.
Also, this is one of the most boring movies I have ever seen. The plot goes nowhere and characters are created only to extend the run time. There is an entire scene devoted to buying ice cream. Nothing important happens, the father get mad at a black guy, this doesn't aide the plot, it just makes me hate all the characters more. It serves to scapegoat the parents further for their opposition to what is clearly a rushed marriage.
Nothing exceptional exists in this film. The dialogue is dull, the story idiotic, the cinematography fine and the music forgettable. The only real success is the acting, which I found passable at worst and mildly impressive in specific scenes thus the three as opposed to two stars. Never watch this.
I think people like this film because it is somehow "important". Remember, just because a film has social commentary it is not suddenly flawless and a classic. Make a good movie first, then worry about your social message.
I hate to be negative so I'll suggest some good films with a similar subject matter so this isn't a complete waste of time for you. Watch Get Out or Twelve Years a Slave for good race commentary combined with excellent film-making and a gripping plot.

This classic movie was really good. Sidney Poitier, Spencer Tracy, Katharine Hepburn, Katharine Houghton, Isabel Sanford, Beah Richards, Roy Glenn, and the rest of the cast did a great job in this movie. The story of the movie was dramatic, heartfelt, and emotional. It's about fighting for love no matter what the circumstances are. If you haven't seen this classic movie yet, check it out sometime. It's a must see.
As important today as the day it was made and brilliant performances from all the characters.  Maybe the best script of the century.
A bit dated.  Still well worth the watch.
One of the best movies to address racism with one of the greatest casts of all time.
I cry every time I watch this, at the end, when he looks in Hepburn's eyes when he says those lines, the Truth and Love in them get's me!
Great social commentary on interracial marriage!
The movie was progressive for it's time, but not as much today. But the acting is still enjoyable. Every actor received an Oscar nod for their performance...except for the legendary Poitier lol
Still relevant today and presented with thoughtful dialogue and wonderfully acted.
True classic and ahead of its time. Loved every minute of it. Cast was awesome. I did shed some tears and loved the message that was being sent to all of us.
Another classic that deals with hatred of Black people.  but this movie is now a classic and get's my four and 1/2 stars!
When I first saw at this movie, I was 15 years old.  Since then I have been always loving this film!!;. Now I'm 40 still loving this film

I still don't get why the black guy (as written) would ever in a million years look twice at the completely vapid white girl (as written).  If I'd been her parents, I'd have thrown her out thirty minutes into the story and then kept the black guy and his mom around for some serious discussions.  Hey, they should re-edit this movie and DO THAT! If you think about it, Katherine Hepburn's (as written and in real life) tears are cause she raised a silly gal/child. (Not the fault of the young lady's performance, but the writers.)

It's hard to discount virtually anything by Stanley Kramer when most of his once-radical observations have now gained far greater acceptance in political and social contexts. Guess Who's Coming to Dinner may not really deliver a particularly revolutionary punch with its relatively conventional love story, but that was a compromise that needed to be made to draw appropriate conclusions regarding the perception of race in America; it just doesn't make it particularly radical viewing in 2020 without taking into account the film's particular historical context. With Poitier, Hepburn, and Tracy (in his final film role), the film is well-stocked with talent, which makes the exceptionally poor performance from Houghton all the more obvious, standing out like a sore thumb. Let it be known, all you have to do to make up for the apparently cardinal sin of being black is to become an enormously successful physician and humanitarian, then you meet the minimum threshold to marry a white girl. (4/5)

Yes, it is dated - but the overall message is not. Brave & bold in 1967, is remain a reminder of ongoing issues in 2020, even if not to the same degree. The only thing that bothers me is that the engaged couple met on vacation 10 days earlier, which is probably not the basis for a lifetime of marriage, mixed race or not. If the story were to be written today, I wonder if "we met on a service project feeding the poor" or "we met while doing environmental cleanup" or something like that would be the scenario instead. That bit of speculation aside, I hope people will watch this film and carefully consider the issues within it. And also consider the question: Can love overcome all trials?

It's easy to watch Guess Who's Coming to Dinner through a 2020 lens and find fault with certain aspects of the film.  Is it dated?  In some respects, yes.  The delivery scene is especially awkward, as is the ice cream scene. Is the central issue still an issue?  Perhaps, but not to the same degree.  The issues today would more likely be the fact that they met ten days earlier and the fourteen-year age difference.  The story of a mixed-race couple and the difficulty the parents have when coming face to face with their own liberal values is a story worth watching, regardless of the year it is watched.  Regardless of the circumstances, does anybody have the right to stand in the way of love?

Although some scenes are dated this film is filled with impressive, powerful and emotive performances. Although I initially learned towards a four star rating the swan song performance by Spencer Tracey earned that extra star; his closing statement gives the film a powerful message delivered with a touch of class. A must watch for any film enthusiast.

Dates badly. Silly even back in ‘67. Cowardly and insulting. And they zip all over with ridiculous plotting. In San Francisco, even in the 60’s.... cocktails with friends at 5:30. Then dash to the airport to pick parents up at 6:30. Then to the house for dinner. And all dash away overseas by 10. Juvenile writing. Oh and of course there is a priest. The black fiance is of course a respected doctor and presents no threat. Unbearably coy and thinks it’s being important.
It is powerful and beautifully acted no matter what year.

i read the negative reviews, from modern critics with shock.  One must go back to 1967.  i was 15, an impressionable teenager in a tumultuous world seeking truth, pure truth as only a child can.  This movie was a life changer, instilling incredible emotions and a spotlight on goodness where few lights shined.  Maybe the critics were not alive in 67?  if they were they would know,
Classic. Great for the times.

The tension throughout the movie is makes for a nice little suspense. Katharine Hepburn is fantastic, as she always is. She really does have a special genuineness about her. She seems like a person with a good soul. It's almost hard to believe that a movie like this came out right after the whole civil rights thing. It's interesting to see how relevant it for that time but also how relevant it is still is to this day. 

The interaction where Tilly was yelling at John telling him he's really going to know what black power really means, was hilarious. The movie's message is a really beautiful one. Love has no boundaries, doesn't see color and doesn't let history or what's happened in the past get in the way. I love Matt (the white girl's father). His speech at the end was so endearing and honest.

I think everyone could learn something from watching this movie. Wonderful acting and an interesting story line. This movie was terrific.
Perfect classic.  Great story, great actors & great message.

Having read about the state of Spencer's health when going to watch this movie I was astounded at how strong his performance was. He was like the old man from Up and the old man in Dennis the Menace's supreme overlord. Having only seen this one Hepburn movie she reminded me strongly of Jessica Lang, whose acting I am a big fan of. The screenplay and dialogue were written fantastically and for a movie without much action it had a surprising amount of rising action and suspense. Hepburn laughing at Spencer's lines felt like genuine displays of her warmth toward him and their scene at the icecream place was just perfect. The scene with the maid's daughter and boyfriend seemed incongruent with the rest of the movie and I was exasperated for much of the movie at the frequent scenes of Hepburn's eyes brimming with tears but none coming out; I grew to be impressed by it at the end as it obviously takes some serious skill to pull off (as seen by the multiple tears falling on the daughter's less talented face at the end). I would've liked for the film score to be more involved, though I can't say I can imagine there being a lot of room for more music, and I thought the heated response from Poitier to his dad near the end was a little heavyhanded, like it was written by a white guy that wasn't sure how a black father and son would speak to each other. This was overall a fantastic movie though!

It was boring to watch and had no real climax. The story itself was interesting at first but more like a commercial that supports biracial couples rather than a feature movie. I fell asleep a few times watching it and even when I would rewind to see what I missed, nothing would really happened that was worth seeing or impacted the story anyway. Not to mention, for a realistic fiction movie that takes place in the 1960's, its a tad pit unrealistic. Lastly I don't like ow the black father is portrayed in the end making it seem as though he's the only one who doesn't approve when he's the only one who really had a valid reason for not approving their marriage. The white father reasons were strictly do to race and nothing more.
Great now and fantastic for it's time

Race relations dramas starring Sidney Poitier from the 1950s and 1960s generally haven't aged well with Lilies of the Field (1963), The Defiant Ones (1958) and this film in particular seeming patronizing and dated by today's standards. This film has the added weight of featuring Spencer Tracy in his last film role alongside longtime professional and personal partner Katharine Hepburn who would win an undeserved Academy Award for her performance. I would recommend that you watch the five to ten minutes of this film that are just Tracy and Hepburn interacting but failing that I would say go out and watch The Graduate (1967) before stepping near this very much a product of it's time film.

Twenty three year old white girl Joanna Drayton, Katharine Houghton, falls in love with older widowed doctor John Prentice, Sidney Poitier, who happens to be African-American. The two face many obstacles in getting married when they return to the United States as Prentice is determined to earn the approval of Drayton's parents, Matt, Spencer Tracy, and Christina, Katharine Hepburn, who each react differently to the news of their daughter's new romance. Matt is worried about the two of them getting married because they have only known each other for two weeks but Christina is trying her best to win him over. More drama is added to the mix when Prentice's parents are invited to dinner with the family and their own prejudices are revealed.

The first comment that I must make is that this a poorly made film from a technical standpoint. The sound cuts out at odd times, certain scenes run far too long and often end awkwardly on lines that don't wrap up conversations adequately. I expected at least a basic level of competence from a film that is so famous but this film didn't deliver as it seemed to rely on it's star wattage and the good will that it's intentions brought to the reception of the film to coast by. The film set also looks cheap as I never believed that the exterior of their house or their ‘view' was even remotely realistic and when considering the fact that this was made in 1967 I'm not as willing to cut it slack as I would be had it been made in the 1950s. This general shoddiness impacted how I viewed the film because it often distracted from the message the film was trying to send and the occasionally effecting performances.

Another big issue with the film is that it's one of those disgusting pictures that exploits a social issue by presenting two supposedly normal characters who eventually adopt a progressive view that is already held by the majority of the audience. In this way the film preaches to the converted, it is saying something that might have been genuinely controversial or refreshing a few generations beforehand but which was held by the majority of Hollywood in 1967. It's frustrating watch a film be so pleased with itself when what it does really isn't all that special or brave. Adding to my dislike of the way the film chooses to present it's social issue they attempt to equalize whites and blacks by portraying the African-American characters as being equally as prejudiced as Matt and Christina. They never really flesh out this plotline and it feels like a strange deflection from the fact that the majority of racism between white Americans and African-Americans comes from the white Americans.

There is also something lacking in the performances as Hepburn and Tracy are occasionally a delight to watch but are used too sparingly to save such a weak film and Houghton and Poitier fail to inject any real spirit into their performances. Houghton seems unable to deliver her lines convincingly as she flits about and uses as many hand gestures as her famous aunt does but doesn't possess the dramatic heft or the knowing humor to pull of this act. She and Poitier also fail to generate any chemistry which makes it difficult for us to feel any real dramatic tension because we don't really care if they end up together. The amount of Academy Award nominations this film received was a crime and it is quite obvious that Anne Bancroft deserved the Best Actress Academy Award for her performance in The Graduate (1967).

The best scenes in the film will only leave you reminiscing about the classic romantic comedies that Hepburn and Tracy appeared in together and in that case I would tell you to see Desk Set (1957) and Adam's Rib (1949) before going near this dud.

It would be completely understandable if anyone criticized this movie for playing it very safe after taking some severe risks at the beginning, and that in doing so the story not only became progressively formulaic; but the characters appeared to be stereotyped and, worst of all, self-contradictory and inconsistent.

That said, the acting here is undoubtedly more than enough to overcome these issues and redeem them, nay, to totally justify these seemingly nonsensical changes and alterations that happened to some of the characters, most noticeably Matt and Christina Drayton. I have seen a lot of great performances that are able to elevate the characters and even the entire movie in general. But, frankly, I have never seen any performance, no matter how superb it may be, that can convince me of what I considered an unmistakably major flaw. What makes me appreciate the acting, in particular, in this movie is that it opened my eyes to some hidden underlying themes of the movie's story, which are more than fundamental to understand the movie properly. If the fabulously realistic and sincere performances, somehow, didn't do the same for you, I suggest you try you figure out some key themes to consider them as you're watching the movie. Two of the most important themes are; the late resurgence of the inherited awful traditions and beliefs, and the undiscovered hypocrisy. Yes, that's how profound this apparently simple film actually is! Of course, the shift in Matt Drayton's attitude could have been executed way more smoothly and maturely; but the abrupt nature of the changes could be fairly, if not quite easily, taken as a reflection of the character's disorder.

Spencer Tracy, in his final role, gave, for lack of a better word, a mature performance that made his character surprisingly believable despite its outwardly incompatible attitudes that made the character of Matt Drayton seem to be immensely problematic. Sidney Poitier's performance, as the handsome African-American Dr. John Prentice, is solid, steady, committed, engaging and relatable at the same time. Katharine Houghton captured the rebelliousness, impetuousness, and also the innocence of her character, Joey, so perfectly. She reminded me quite a bit of another Katharine; Katharine Ross as Elaine Robinson in The Graduate, which was, also coincidentally, released at the same year, 1967. But it's Katharine Hepburn who stole the show here with her Oscar-winning performance that I personally consider as one of the best low-key performances in a leading female role I've ever seen in film!

I would be lying if I said that I found the second half of the movie half as entertaining and riveting. Nevertheless, the dialogue was much better at the second half (the final monologue is simply remarkable!) as it was at the first, which is noticeably elevated by, once again, the incredible acting.

The movie is decidedly filled with stereotypical characters, but the only one that bothered me is the maid, Tillie, whom I didn't find to be funny at all; actually she is quite annoying. Her character's motivations and attitudes are justified, though.

Guess Whoâ(TM)s Coming to Dinner is an essential classic 1960s film, and one of the best films that examine prejudice and racism; it tackles its weighty themes with surprising depth, humor and breeziness. It's also very relevant nowadays. And there is no doubt that it has major influences on hundreds of movies that came after it, especially today's.

I knew a lot about Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner before I sat down to watch it, and my biggest concern was whether they could keep such a simple premise interesting for that long. Not only does the movie manage to be interesting, it is delightful for the entire runtime. There are so many moments that will stick with me because they made me laugh, cry, or cheer. The movie includes people who are on every side when it comes to views on interracial relationships, so it feels like it should speak to all audiences (except the Hilary St. George’s of the world who can shut up and go away.) There is so much heart to this movie, because the characters clearly love one another dearly. Fathers and mothers love their children despite everything, husbands and wives love one another more than they can say, and even friends are loved like family. I felt like this entire movie embraced me like a warm hug, despite the hot-button issue that is at the center of it all. One big reason Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner is so successful is that amazing cast. Sidney Poitier has immeasurable charm and uses it to make the point that he’s just a man and he shouldn’t be defined by his color. He makes for a nice grounded counterpoint to Katharine Houghton’s bubbly lightness. Katharine Hepburn is astounding, and says so many things with just her eyes. You can see her opinions change as the film progresses without her needing to say how she’s feeling. Spencer Tracy is left with one of the toughest roles of the whole movie. It is remarkable how he is able to be the main character who is opposed to the wedding, sounding like a complete hypocrite, and yet still be sympathetic. Roy Glenn and Beah Richards don’t get as much screen-time, but their impact is vital to the film as well, and they both get important scenes when they arrive. Not to mention Cecil Kellaway who had one of my favorite moments in the entire film. I know there will be audiences who will not gravitate to this style of movie. Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner establishes its premise early and then spends the rest of the time with characters just talking it through. It feels like a stage play because so much of the film takes place in one house, and there is not much action aside from walking around. The closest they come to a stunt was a fender-bender between two cars at an ice cream parlor. However, when the dialogue is written this well, I don’t care one bit. I was riveted as much as I am watching Die Hard. I can’t say enough about the big speeches in this movie. Almost every character in the film gets their moment to let loose with a monologue at some point. They are written so well that they help define the character who is giving the speech, and also articulate an important point related to the central conflict of the film. I don’t know how much more I can say about Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner. It blew me away, and I now need to own it so I can watch it 10 more times at least.
